editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AS IT HATH BEEN SVNdry times acted by the Children of Paules.
AT LONDON, ❧ Printed for A. I. and are to be ſould at the ſigne of the white horſe in Paules Churchyard. An. 1607.

div.head: Inductio.
div.stage: Enter Michaelmas Terme in a whitiſh Cloake, new come vp out of the countrey, a Boye bringing his Gowne after him!

sp.speaker: Micha:
sp.p: BOye?

sp.speaker: Boye:
sp.p: Here ſit!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Lay by my conſcience, giue mee my Gowne,
That weede is for the country,
We muſt be ciuill now, and match out Euill,
Who firſt made Ciuill, blacke; he pleas'd the Deuill;
So; now know I where I am, me thinkes already
I graſpe beſt part of the Autumnian bleſſing
In my contentious fadome, my hand's free,
From wronger and from wronged I haue fee,
And what by ſweat from the rough earth they drawe,
Is to enrich this ſiluer harueſt, Lawe,
And ſo through wealthy variance, and fat brawle,
The Barne is made but Steward to the Hall;
Come they vp thicke inough?

sp.speaker: Boye:
sp.p: Oh like hops and harlots ſir!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: Why do'ſt thou couple them?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Oh very aptlye, for as the hop well boiled will make a man not ſtand vppon his leggs: ſo the harlot in time will leaue a man no leggs to ſtand vppon!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Such another and bee my heyre, I haue no Childe,
Yet haue I wealth would redeeme beggery,
I thinke it be a curſe both here and forraine,
Where bags are fruitful'ſt, there the womb's moſt barren,
The poore ha's all our children, we their wealth;
Shall I be prodigall when my life cooles,
Make thoſe my heyres whome I haue beggar'd; Fooles?
It would be wondrous; rather beggar more,
Thou ſhalt haue heyres enow, thou keep'ſt a whore,
And here comes kindred too with no meane purſes,
Yet ſtriue to be ſtill bleſt with Clients curſes.

div.stage: Muſicke playing. Enter the other 3. Termes, the firſt bringing in a fellowe poore, which the other 2. aduanceth, giuing him rich Apparell, apage, and a pandar. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: What ſubtiltie haue we here? a fellowe
Shrugging for lifes kind benefits, ſhift and heate,
Crept vp in 3. Termes, wrapt in ſilke and ſiluer,
So well appointed too with Page and Pandar,
It was a happy gale that blew him hether.

list.item: 1. Thou father of the Termes haile to thee.
2. May much contention ſtill keepe with thee.
3. Many new fooles come vp and fee thee.
2. Let e'm paye deere ynough that ſee thee.

lg.l: And like Aſſes vſe ſuch men,
When their load's off, turne e'm to graze agen.
And may our wiſh haue full effect, Many a ſuite, and much neglect.
And as it hath beene often found, Let the Clients cups come round.
Helpe your poore kinſmen when you ha got e'm. You may drinke deepe, leaue vs the bottom;
Or when there is a lambe falne in, Take you the lambe, leaue vs the skin.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Your dutie and regard hath mou'd vs,
Neuer till now wee thought you lou'd vs,
Take comfort from our words, and make no doubt,
You ſhall haue ſuites come ſixteen times about.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We humbly thanke the patron of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: With what a vaſſaile—appetite they Gnawe,
On our reuerſions; and are proud,
Coldly to taſt our meates, which eight returnes
Serue in to vs as courſes;
One day our writs like wilde-fowle flye abroad,
And then returne or'e Cities, Townes, and Hills,
With Clyents like dryed ſtrawes betweene their bills;
And 'tis no few birds picke to build their Neaſts,
Nor no ſmall money that keeps Drabs and Feaſts!

div.p: But Gentlemen, to ſpread my ſelfe open vnto you, in cheaper Termes I ſalute you, for ours haue but ſixpenny fees all the yeare long, yet wee diſpatch you in two howers, without demur; your Suites hang not long here after Candles be lighted: Why we call this play by ſuch a deere and chargeable Title, Michaelmas Tearme? Knowe it conſents happilye to our purpoſe, tho perhaps faintlie to the interpretation of many; for he that expects any great quarrels in Lawe to bee handled here, will be fondly deceaued, this onely preſents thoſe familiar accidents, which happend in Towne in the circumference of thoſe ſixe weekes, whereof Michaelmas Terme is Lord: Sat ſapienti, I hope there's no fooles i'th houſe!
div.stage: Enter at one dore Maister Rerrage, meetiug Maister Salewood.

sp.speaker: Salewood:
sp.p: What Maſter Rerrage?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Maſter Salewood▪ Exceedingly well met in Towne, comes your Father vp this Terme?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why he was here three dayes before the Exchequer gapte.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fye, ſuch an earlie Termer?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
Hee's not to bee ſpoke withall, I dare not aske him
bleſſing, till the laſt of Nouember.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And how looks thy little venturing Cooſen?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Faith like a Lute that ha's all the ſtringes broke, no bodie will meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fye, there are Doctors enow in Towne will ſtring her againe, and make her ſound as ſweete as ere ſhee did, is ſhee not married yet?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sh' as no lucke, ſome may better ſteale a horſe than others looke on. I haue knowen a virgin of fiue baſtardes wedded, faith when all's donne we muſt bee faine to marrie her into the North I'me affrayd.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: But will ſhee paſſe ſo thinke you?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Puh, any thinge that is warme ynough is good ynough for them; ſo it come in the likenes, tho the Deuill be in't, the'ile venture the fiering.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: They're worthy ſpirits yfaith, heard you the Newes?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Miſtris Difficult is falne a widdowe.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Say true, is Maſter Difficult the Lawyer dead?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Eaſilie dead ſir.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Pray when died hee?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What a queſtion's that? when ſhould a Lawyer dye but in the vacation, hee ha's no leiſure to die in the Tearmetime, beſide the Noyſe there would fetch him againe.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Knew you the nature of his diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith ſome ſay he dyed of an old griefe he had, that the vacation was foureteene weekes long.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: And very likely. I knew 'twould kill him at laſt, t'as troubled him a long time, hee was one of thoſe that would faine haue brought in the hereſie of a fift Tearme, often crying with a loud voice, oh why ſhould we looſe Bartholmew weeke?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He ſauours, ſtop your Noſe, no more of him.

div.stage: Enter master Cockstone, a Gentleman meeting maſter Eaſye of Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Yong maiſter Eaſye, let me ſalute you ſir, when came you?

sp.speaker: Eaſye:
sp.p: I haue but Inn'd my horſe ſince maſter Cockstone.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: You ſeldome viſit London maſter Eaſye,
But now your Fathers dead tis your onely courſe,
Here's gallants of all ſizes, of all laſts,
Here you may fit your foote, make choyſe of thoſe
Whome your affection may reioyce in:

sp.speaker: Eaſye:
sp.l: You haue eaſily poſſeſt me I am free,
Let thoſe liue hindes that know not libertie.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Maſter Rerrage?

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: Good maſter Salewood, I am proud of your ſociety.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What gentleman might that bee?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: One maſter Eſay, h'as good • nd in Eſſex,
a faire free-breſted Gentleman, ſomewhat too open,
bad in man, worſe in woman,
the Gentrye-fault at firſt, he is yet freſh
and wants the Citie powdring, but what newes?
I'ſt yet a match twixt maſter Qomodoes the rich Drapers
daughter and your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith ſir, I am vildly riuald!

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Vildly? by whome.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: One Andrewe Lethe crept to a little warmth, and now ſo proud that he forgets all ſtormes, one that nere wore apparell, but like ditches 'twas caſt before hee had it, now ſhines bright in rich embroderies, him maſter Quomodo affects, the daughter him, the mother onely mee, I reſt moſt doubtfull, my ſide being wookeſt.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Yet the mothers ſide being ſurer than the Fathers, it may proue, men pleade for money beſt, women for loue.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Slid maſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: How then, affraid of a woollen draper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He warn'd mee his houſe, and I hate hee ſhould ſee me abroad!

div.stage: Quomodo with his two ſpirits, Shortyard and Falſelight.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Oh my 2. ſpirits Shortyard and Falſelight, you that haue ſo enricht me, I haue induſtrie for you both?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Then doe you pleaſe vs beſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Wealthy employment.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: You make me icth ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: You Falſelight as I haue directed you.

sp.speaker: Falſ:
sp.p: I am nimble.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Goe, make my courſe commodities, looke, ſeeke, with ſubtile art beguile the honeſt eye, be neere to my trapwindowe, cunning Falſelight.

sp.speaker: Falſ:
sp.p: I neuer failde it yet.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: I know thou didſt not;
But now to thee my true and ſecret Shortyard,
Whome I dare truſtee'n with my wife,
Thou nere didſt miſtris harme, but maſter, good,
There are too few of thy name Gentlemen,
And that we feele, but Citizens abundance,
I haue a taske for thee my pregnant ſpirit,
To exerciſe thy poynted wits vppon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Giue it me, for I thirſt.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: Thine care ſhall drinke it,
Know then I haue not ſpent this long Vacation
Onely for pleaſures ſake, giue me the man
Who out of recreation culls aduantage,
Diues into ſeaſons, neuer walkes, but thinkes,
Ne • ides, but plots, my iourney was toward Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Moſt true?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Where I haue ſeene what I deſire.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: A woman?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Puh; a woman, yet beneath her, that which ſhee often treades on. Yet commands her land, fayre neate Land.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: What is the marke you ſhoote at.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Why the fayreſt to cleaue the heire in twayne, I meane his Title to murder his eſtate, ſtifle his right in ſome ſome deteſted priſon, there are means and waies enow to hooke in Gentry, beſides our deadlye enmitye which thus ſtands they'r buſye 'bout our wiues, We 'bout their Lands.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.l: Your reuenge is more glorious,
To be a cuckold is but for one life,
When land remaines to you, your heire, or wife!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Ah ſirrah, doe we ſtinge'm, this freſh gallant rode newly vp before me!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I beſeech his name.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Yong maſter Eaſye.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Eaſye? It may fall right.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: I haue enquir'd his haunt, ſtay, ha, I that, 'tis, thats he, thats he!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Happilie!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Obſerue, take ſurely note of him, hee's freſh and free ſhift thy ſelfe ſpeedily into the ſhape of gallantrye, Ile ſwell thy purſe with angels, keepe foote by foote with him, out-dare his expences, flatter, dice, and brothell to him, giue him a ſweete taſt of Senſuality, traine him to euery waſtfull ſin, that he may quickly neede health, but eſpecially money, rauiſh him with a dame or twoo, bee his bawde for once, Ile bee thine for euer, drinke drunke with him, creepe into bed to him, kiſſe him and vndoo him, my ſweete ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Let your care dwell in me ſoone ſhall it ſhine, What ſubtiltie is in man, that is not mine.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: O my moſt cherefull ſpirit, goe, diſpatch, Gentrye is the cheife fiſh we Tradeſmen catch.

sp.speaker: Eaſye:
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Oh, they are bils for Chambers.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: Againſt Saint Andrewes, at a Painters houſe, ther's a faire chamber ready furniſht to bee let, the houſe not onely endewed with a newe faſhion forepart, but which is more conuenient for a Gentleman, with a very prouident backe-doore.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why here's vertue ſtill; I like that thing that's neceſſary, as well as pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: What newes in yonder paper.

sp.speaker: Rerra:
sp.p: Ha? ſeeke you for newes, there's for you!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Whoſe tis? in the name of the blacke Angels, Andro Gruill.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No, Andro Lethe!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Lethe?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Has forgot his fathers name, poore Walter Gruill that begot him, fed him, and brought him vp.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not hither.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No; 'twas from his thoughts, hee brought him vp belowe.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: But do's he paſſe for Lethe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Mongſt ſtrange eyes that no more knowe him, then he knowes himſelfe, thats nothing now, for maſter Andro Lethe, a gentleman of moſt receiued parts, forgetfulnes, Luſt, Impudence, and Falſhood, and one eſpeciall Courtly quality; to wit, no wit at all, I am his Riuall for Quomodoes daughter, but hee knowes it not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Has ſpyed vs ore his paper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Oh thats a warning to make our duties ready.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Salute him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Puh, wiſh his health a while, heele be laide ſhortly, let him gorge Veniſon for a time, our doctors will bring him to dry mutton; ſeeme reſpectiue to make his pride ſwell like a Toade with dewe.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Maſter Lethe!

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Sweete maſter Lethe.

sp.speaker: Lathe:
sp.p: Gentlemen your pardon, I remember you not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why we ſupt with you laſt night ſir!

sp.speaker: Lethe:
sp.l: Oh cry you mercy, 'tis ſo long agoe,
I had quite forgot you, I muſt be forgiuen,
Acquaintaince, deere ſocietie, ſuites and things,
Do ſo flowe to mee; that had I not the better memorie!
Twould be a wonder I ſhould know my ſelfe,
Eſteeme is made of ſuch a dizzy mettall;
I haue receiu'd of many gifts ore night
Whome I haue forgot ere morning, meeting the men,
I wiſht em to remember me agen,
They doo ſo: then if I forget agen,
I know what helpt before, that will helpe then,
This is my courſe, for memorie I haue been told
Twentie preſerues, the beſt I find is gold;
Ey truely! are you not knights yet, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: No, that muſt bee lookt into, tis your owne ſault,
I haue ſome ſtore of Veniſon, where ſhall we deuoure it,
Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.l: The horne were a fit place.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: For Veniſon, fit,
The horne hauing chaſt it,
At the horne—weele Rime to that.—

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Taſt it.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Waſt it.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Caſt it.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Thats the true rime indeed, wee hunt our Veniſon
twice I tell you, firſt out a'th parke, next out a'th Bellie.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: Firſt dogs take paines to make it fit for men,
Then men take payne to make it fit for dogs.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: Why this is kindnes, a kind Gallant, you,
And loue to giue the dogs more than their due,
We ſhall attend you ſir.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I pray doo ſo.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: The horne.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Eaſily remembred that you know!

div.p:
But now vnto my preſent buſines, the Daughter yeildes, and Quomodo conſents, onely my miſtris Quomodo, her mother without regard runs full againſt mee, and ſticks hard! Is there no law for a woman that will run vpon a man at her owne apperill. Why ſhould not ſhee conſent, knowing my state, my ſudaine fortunes, I can command a cuſterd, and other bakemeats, death of ſturgeon, I could keepe houſe with nothing, what friends haue I? how wellam I beloued, ee'n quite throughout the ſcullery, not conſent? tis ee'n as I haue writ, Ile be hang'd, and ſhee loue mee not herſelfe & wold rather preſerue me, as a priuate friend to her own pleaſures, than any way aduance her daughter vpon me to beguile herſelfe, then how haue I relieued her in that poynt, let me peruſe this letter. Good miſtris Quomodo, or rather as I hope ere the Terme end, mother Quomodo, ſince only your conſent keeps a loofe off and hinders the copulation of your daughter, what may I thinke, but that it is a meere affection in you, doating vppon ſome ſmall inferiour vertue of mine, to draw me in vpon your ſelf, if the caſe stand ſo, I haue comfort for you: for this you may well aſſure your ſelfe, that by the marriage of your daughter I haue the better meanes and opportunity to your ſelfe, and without the leaſt ſuſpition. This is moouing ſtuffe, and that workes best with a Citizens wife, but who ſhall I get to conuey this now: my Page I halent forth, my Pandar I haue imployd about the country, to looke out ſome third ſiſter, or entice ſome diſcontented Gentlewoman from her husband, whōe the laying out of my appetite ſhall maintaine, nay Ile deale like an honourable Gentleman, Ile bee kinde to women, that which I gather i'th day, Ile put into their purſes at night, you ſhall haue no cauſe to raile at me, no faith, Ile keepe you in good faſhion Ladyes, no meaner men then knights ſhall ranſome home your gownes, and recouer your ſmocks, Ile not dallye with you—ſome poore widdow woman would come as a neceſſary bawd now: and ſee where fitly comes—my mother! curſe off
pouerty do's ſhee come vp to ſhame me, to betray my birth, and caſt ſoyle vpon my new Suite, let her paſſe me, Ile take no notice of her, Scuruye—murrey—Carſey!

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: By your leaue and like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Then I muſt proudly venture it; to me good woman.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: I beſeech one word with your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Prethe be breife then.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: Pray can your worſhip tell me any tydings of one Andro Gruill, a poore ſonne of mine owne.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I know a gallant Gentleman of the name, one maſter Andro Gruill and well receiude amongſt Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: That not he then!
Hee is no Gentleman that I meane.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Good woman if he be a Gruill, hee's a Gentleman i'th mornings: thats a Gentleman a'th firſt, you canot tel me

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: No truely, his father was an honeſt vpright Tooth-drawer.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: O my teeth.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: An't pleaſe your worſhip, I haue made a fore iourney out, all this vacant time, to come vp and ſee my ſonne Andro, poore Walter Gruill his Father has layd his life, and left mee a lone woman, I haue not one husband in all the world, therefore my comming vp is for reliefe an't like your worſhip, hoping that my ſonne Andro is in ſome place about the Kitchin.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Kitchin, puh, fah.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Or a ſeruingman to ſome Kinght of worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Oh let mee not indure her! Knowe you not mee good woman?

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alaſſe, an't pleeaſe your worſhip, I neuer ſawe ſuch a glorious ſuite ſince the hower I was • erſend.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Good, ſhee knowes me not, my glory do's diſquire mee,
Beſide my poorer name being drencht in Lethe,
Sheele hardly vnderſtand me, what a freſh ayre can doo!
I may employ her as a priuate drudge,
To paſſe my letters and ſecure my luſt,
And nere be noted mine, to ſhame my blood,
And drop my ſtayning birth vppon my raiment, faith good
woman you will hardly get to the ſpeech of maſter Andro,
I tell you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: No?
Marry hang him, and like your Worſhip, I haue knowen the day when no body carde to ſpeake to him!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You muſt take heed how you ſpeak ill of him now I cantell you; hee's ſo employde.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Imployde for what?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: For his behauiour, wiſdome, and other vertues.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: His vertues? no tis well knowen, his father was too poore a man to bring him vp to any vertues; hee can ſcarce write and reade.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Hee's the better regarded for that amongſt Courtiers, for thats but a needy qualitie!

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: If it be ſo, then heele be great ſhortly, for he has no good parts about him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Well good woman, or mother, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alack the day, I know your worſhip ſcornes to cal me mother: tis not a thing fit for your worſhip indeede, ſuch a ſimple old woman as I am.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: In pitty of thy long iourney, there's ſix-pence Britiſh: tend vpon me, I haue buſines for you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Ile waite vpon your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Two pole off at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: I am a cleane ould woman, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: It goes not by cleannes here good woman, if you were fowler, ſo you were brauer, you might come neerer.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Nay and that be the faſhion, I hope I ſhall (Exit. get it ſhortly, there's no woman ſo ould but ſhe may learne; and as an old Lady delights in a young Page or monckey, ſo there are young Courtiers will be hungry vpon an old woman, I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter Le • hes Pandar with a Country wench.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Come, leaue your puling and ſighing.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Beſhrew you now, why did you entice me from my father

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Why? to thy better aduancement, wouldſt thou a pretty
beautifull—Iuicy ſquall, liue in a poore thrumbd houſe i'th cuntry in ſuch ſeruile—habiliments, and may well paſſe for a gentlewoman i'th Citie, do's not 5 hundred do ſo thinkst thou, and with worſe faces, oh, now in theſe latter dayes, the Deuill raygning tis an age for clouen creatures? but why ſad now? yet indeed tis the faſhion of any Curtizan to be ſea-ſicke i'th firſt Voyage, but at next ſhee proclaimes open wars, like a beaten ſouldier: why Northampton-ſhire Laſſe do'ſt dreame of virginity now? remember a looſe-bodied Gowne wench, & let it goe, wires, & tyres, bents and bums, felts and falls, thou that ſhalt deceiue the world, that Gentlewomen indeed ſhall not be knowen from others; I haue a maſter to whome I muſt prefer thee, after the aforeſayd decking, Lethe by name, a man of one moſt admired property, he can both loue thee and for thy better aduancement be thy Pandar himſelfe, an exlent ſparke of humility.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Well heauen forgiue you, you traine me vp too't.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Why I doe acknowledge it, and I thinke I doe you a pleaſure in't.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: And if I ſhould proue a harlot now, I ſhould be bound to curſe you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Bound? nay and you proue a harlot, youle be looſe ynough.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: If I had not a deſire to goe like a gentlewoman, you ſhould be hangd, ere you ſhould get me too't I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Nay thats certain, nor a 1000. more of you, I know, you are all chaſt ynough, till one thing or other tempt you •
deny a Sattin gowne and you dare now?

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: You knowe I haue no power to doo't, and that makes you ſo wilfull: for what woman is there ſuch a beaſt that will deny any thing that is good.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: True they will not, moſt diſſembler.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: No, and ſhee beare a braue mind ſhee will not I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Why, therfore take heart, faint not at all,
Women nere riſe, but when they fall,
Let a man breake, hee's gone, blowen vp,
A womans breaking ſets her vp,
Virginitie is no Citie—Trade,
You're out a'th Freedome, when you're a mayde,
Downe with the lattis tis but thin,
Let courser beauties worke within:
Whome the light mocks, thou art faire and freſh,
The guilded flies, will light vpon thy fleſh.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.l: Beſhrew your ſweet enchantments, you have wun.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.l: How eaſily ſoft women are vndone:
So farewell holeſome weeds where treaſure pants,
And welcome ſilkes, where lyes diſeaſe and wants:
Come wench, now flow thy Fortunes in to bleſſe thee,
Ile bring thee where thou ſhalt be taught to dreſſe thee!

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Oh as ſoone as may be, I am in a ſwone till I bee a gentlewoman, and you know what fleſh is mans meate, tell it be dreſt.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Moſt certain, no more a woman.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Rerrage, Salewood, Lethe, Eaſye, with Shortyard alias Blastfield, at dice.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Gentlemen I ha ſworne Ile change the roome: dice?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You ſee I'me patient gentlemen▪

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: I, the feinds in't, you're patient, you put vp all. Deuils.

sp.speaker:
R ••
▪
sp.p: Come set me gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: An Essexgenrleman ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: An vnfortunate one ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: Hees ſecond to my boſome.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Ile giue you that comfort then ſir, you muſt not want money as long as you are in towne ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: No ſir?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I am bound in my loue to him to ſee you furniſht, and in that comfort I recouer my ſalute agen ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: Then I deſire to be more deere vnto you.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I rather ſtudy to be deare vnto you—boy, fill ſome wine.—I knew not what faire impreſſier I receiud, at firſt, but I began to affect your ſocietie very ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: I count my ſelfe the happier.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: To maſter Alſup ſir, to whoſe remembrance, I could loue to drinke till I were paſt remembrance.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I ſhall keepe Chriſtmaſſe with him ſit, where your health ſhall likewiſe vndoubtedly be remembred, and therevpon I pledge you:—I would ſue for your name ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Your ſuite ſhall end in one Tearme ſir: my name is Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Kind maiſter Blaſtfield, your deerer acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Nay come, will ye draw in Gentlemen? ſet me:

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Faith I'me ſcatterd.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall not giue out ſo meanely of your ſelfe in my companie for a Million: make Such priuie to your diſgrace? you'r a Gentleman of faire fortunes; keep me your reputation; ſet 'em all, there's crownes fo you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Sir you binde me infinitely in theſe courteſies.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You muſt alwayes haue a care of your Reputation here in Town maiſter Eaſie, altho you ride downe with nothing, it skils not.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I'me glad you tell me that yet, then I',e indifferent. Well, come: who throwes? I ſet all theſe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: This ſame maiſter Lethe here begins to vndo vs agen.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ah ſir, I came not hither but to win.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And then you'le leaue vs, thats your faſhion.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Hee's baſe that viſits not his friends:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: But hee's more baſe taht carries out his winnings.
None will doe ſo but thoſe haue baſe beginnings

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: It is a thing in vſe and euer was, I paſſe this time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I wonder you ſhould paſſe. And that you're ſufferd.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Tut, the Dice are ours,
Then wonder not at thoſe that haue moſt powrs▪

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: The Diuell and his Angels.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Are theſe they? Welcome deere Angels, where y'are curſt nere ſtay.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Heere's lucke.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Lets ſearch him Gentlemen, I think he wears a ſmock:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I knew the time, he wore not halfe a ſhirt, iuſt like a Pee.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: No, how did he for the Reſt?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Faith he compounded with a couple of Napkins at Barnet, and ſo truſ'd vp the lower parts.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Twas a prettie ſhift yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But maiſter Lethe ha's forgot that too.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: A miſchiefe on't to looſe all: I could—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay but good Ma Eaſie, do not do your ſelf that tirannie I beſeech you, I muſt not ha you alter your body now for the Purge of a little money: you vndoe me and you doe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Twas al I brought vp with me, I proteſt maſter Blaſtſield, all my rent till next quarter.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Pox of money, talke not on't I beſeech you, what ſaid I to you? Maſſe I am out of caſh my ſelfe too,—Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Run preſently to maſter Gum the Mercer, and wil him to tell out two or three hundred pound for mee, or more according as he is furniſht: Ile viſit him ith morning ſay.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſaid ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Doe you heare boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If maſter Gum bee not ſufficiently readie, call vppon maſter Profit the Goldſmith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It ſhall be done ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I know I was not ſent yet now is the time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let them both reſt till another occaſion: you ſhall not need to run ſo farre at this time, take one nier hand go to Ma. Quomodo the Draper, and will him to furniſh mee inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I goe ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: It ſeemes y'are wel knowne maſter Blaſtfield, and your credite verie ſpacious here ith Citie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Maſter Eaſie, let a man beare himſelfe portly, the whorſons will creepe to him a'th their bellies, and their wiues a'th their backs: ther's a kinde of bolde grace expected throughout all the parts of a Gentleman: then for your obſeruances, a man muſt not ſo much as ſpit but within line and faſhion. I tell you what I ha done: ſomtimes I carrie my water all London ouer, onely to deliuer it proudly at the Standard, and do I paſſe altogether vnnoted thinke you? No, a man can no ſooner peep out his head, but ther's a bow bent at him out of
ſome watch tower, or other.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: So readily ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Puſh, you know a bowe's quickely readie, tho a Gun belong a charging, and will ſhoote fiue times to his once, Come, you ſhall beare your ſelfe Iouially: take heede of ſetting your lookes to your loſſes, but rather ſmile vppon your ill lucke, and inuite 'em to morrow to another breakefaſt of Bones.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay ile forſweare dicing.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? peace? I am aſhamed to heare you: will you ceaſſe in the firſt loſſe, ſhewe mee one Gentleman that ere did it? Fie vppon't I muſt vſe you to companie I perceyue, youde be ſpoilde elſe: forſweare Dice? I would your friends heard you yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay I was but in ieſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I hope ſo, what woulde Gentlemen ſay of you? there goes a Gull that keepes his money, I would not haue ſuch a report goe on you, for the Worlde as long as you are in my companie. Why man fortune alters in a Minute, I ha knowne thoſe haue recouered ſo much in an houre, their purſes were neuer ſicke after.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Oh worſe then conſumption of the Liuer! conſumption of the patrimonie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? marke their humours maſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Forgiue me, my poſte • itie, yet vngotten.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Thats a penitent Maudlen Dicer.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Few knowe the ſweets that the plaine life allowes. Vilde ſonne that ſurfets of his fathers browes.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Laugh at him maſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Ile bee damn'd and theſe bee not the bones of ſome queane that couzened me in her life, and now conſumes mee after her death.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Thats the true-wicked-blaſphemous, and ſoul-ſhuddering Dicer, that will curſe you all ſeruice time, & attribute his ill lucke alwayes to one Drab or other.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Dick, Hell-gill: the hapie Newes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I haue her for you ſir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Peace, what is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Yong, beautifull and plump.—a delicate peece of ſin.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Of what parentage?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Oh a Gentlewoman of a great houſe.

sp.speaker: Leh.
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Shee newly came out of a Barne; yet too good for a Tooth-drawers ſonne.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Is ſhe wife or maide?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: That which is dantieſt, Maide

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ide rather ſhee'd beene a wife.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: A wife ſir, why?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Oh Adulterie is a great deale ſweeter in my minde.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Diſeaſes gnaw thy bones. I thinke ſhe has deſerud to be a wife ſir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: That will moue well.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Her firſtlinge ſhall be mine. Swine looke but for the huskes, the meate be thine.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: How now Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maiſter Quomodo takes your worſhips greeting exceeding kindely, and in his commendations returnes this anſwere, that your worſhip ſhall not be ſo apt to receiue it, as hee willing to lend it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, we thanke him yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Troth, and you ha reaſon to thanke him ſir, t'was a verie friendly anſwere.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Puſh, a Gentleman that keeps his daies euen here ith City (as I my ſelfe watch to doe) ſhall haue many of thoſe anſweres in a tweluemonth, maiſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I promiſe you ſir I admire your carriage, and begin to hold a mor reu'rend reſpect of you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not ſo I beſeech you, I giue my friends leaue to bee inward with me,—will you walke Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Wee're for you. Preſent her with this Iewell my firſt token.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: There are certaine Country-men without enquiring for maiſter Rerage, and maiſter Salewood.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Tennants!

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: Thou reuiu'ſt vs Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: When's our next meeting Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: To morrow night, This Gentleman, by me inuites you all, Do you not Maiſter Eaſie?

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Freely ſir.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: We doe imbrace your loue—a pure freſh Gull

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Thus make you men at parting duetifull, And reſt beholding to you, tis the ſlight To be remembred, when you'r out of ſight.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: A prettie vertue.

div.stage: Enter the Countrie-Wenches Father, that was ent •• c'd for Leth:

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Where ſhall I ſeeke her now?—oh if ſhe knew The Dangers that attend on womens liues, She would rather lodge vnder a poore thatcht Roofe Then vnder carued ſeelings: ſhe was my ioy, And all content that I receiu'd from life, My deere and onely Daughter: What ſaies the Note ſhe left, let mee agen With ſtayeder greefe peruſe it—Father? wonder not at my ſo ſuddaine departure, without your leaue or knowledge, thus vnder pardon I excuſe it, had you had knowledge of it, I know you would haue ſought to reſtraine it, and hinder me from what I haue long deſirde, being now happilye preferr'd to a Gentlemans ſeruice in London; about Holborne, if you pleaſe to ſend, you may heare well of me—
sp.l: As falſe as ſhe is diſobedient,
Iy'e made larger inquirie, left no place
(Where Gentrie keepes) vnſought, yet cannot heare,
Which driues me moſte into a ſhamefull feare:
Woe worth th' infected cauſe that makes me viſit
This man-deuouring Cittie—where I ſpent
My vnſhapen youth, to be my ages curſſe,
And ſurfetted away my name and ſtate,
In ſwiniſh Riots, that now being ſober,
I doe awake, a Begger,—I may hate her.
Whoſe youth voides wine, his age is curſt with water,
Oh heauens! I know the price of ill, too well,
What, the confuſions are in whome they dwell,
And how ſoone Maides are to their Ruins won
One minute, and aeternally vndone:
So in mine may it: may it not be thus?—
Though ſhe be poore, her honours preceous,
May be my preſent forme, and her foud feare,
May chace her from me, if her eye ſhould getme,
And therefore as my loue and wants aduiſe.
Ile ſerue vntill I finde her in diſguiſe.
Such is my care to fright her from baſe euils
I leaue calme ſtate to liue amongſt you, deuils.

div.stage: Lethes Mother enters with Quomodoes wife with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Were theſe fit wordes thinke you to be ſent to anye Cittizens wiſe, to enioy the Daughter, and loue the mother too for a neede? I would foulye ſcorne that man, that ſhould loue me onely for a neede I tell you: and heere the Knaue writes agen, that by the mariage of my Daughter, a has the better meanes and opportunitie to my ſelfe, hee lies in his Throate like a villaine, he has no opportunitie of mee, for all that, tis for his betters to haue opportunitie of me, and that he ſhall well knowe—a baſe proud knaue—a has forgot how he came vp, & brought two of his countrie men to giue their words to my huſband for a ſute of greene Karſey, a has forgot all this, and how does hee appeare to me, when his white Sattin ſuttes on, but like a Magot crept out of a Nutſhell, a faire bodie and a foule necke, thoſe partes that are couered of him, lookes indifferent well, becauſe we cannot ſee e'm elſe for all his clenſing, pruning and paring, hee's not worthy a Brokers Daughter, and ſo tell him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I will indeede forſooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: And as for my Childe, I hope ſheele bee ruld in Time, though ſhe be foliſh yet & not be carryed away with a caſt of Manchets, a Bottle of wine, or a Cuſtard, and ſo I pray certifie him.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: He doe your errant effectually.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Art thou his Ant—or his—

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Alaſſe—I am a poore drudge of his.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Faith and thou wert his Mother, he would make thee his drudge I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Marrie out vppon him, ſir reuerence of your miſtrisſhip

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Heer's ſomewhat for thy paines, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Tis more then he gaue me ſince I came to him.

div.stage: Enter Quomodo and his Daughter Su.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now, what prating haue we heare? whiſpers, dumſhowes? why Tomazin, goo too—my ſhop is not altogether ſo darke as ſome of my neighbours, where a man may be made Cuckold at one ende, while hee's meaſuring with his yard at tother.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Onely commendations ſent from Maiſter Lethe your worſhipfull Sonne in law that ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Q • o.
sp.p: Oh, & that you like not▪ he that can make vs rich in cuſtom, ſtrong in friends, happy in ſuites, bring vs into all the romes a ſundaies, from the leads to the ſeller, pop vs in with Veniſon til wee cracke agen, & ſend home the reſt in an honorable Napkin—this man you like not forſooth?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: But I like him father.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: My bleſſing goe with thy liking

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: A number of our Cittizens hold our credit by't to come home drunk, and ſay wee ha beene at Court: then how much more credit i'ſt to be drunke there indeede?

sp.speaker: Qno • .
sp.p: Tut, thy Mothers a foole—pray whats Maiſter Rerage whom you pleade for ſo?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Why, firſt he is a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, hee's often firſt a Gentleman that's laſt a begger.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: My father tels you true, what ſhould I do with a gentleman, I knowe not which way to lye with him.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis truetoo—thou knowſt beſide, we vndoe Gentlemen dayly

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: That makes ſo few of e'm marrie with our Daughters, vnles it be one green foote or other▪ next, M. Rerage has land & liuing, tother but his walke i'th ſtreet, & his ſnatching dyet, hee's able to entertaine you in a faire houſe of his owne, tother in ſome nooke or corner, or place vs behind the cloath like a company of Puppe • s: at his houſe you ſhall bee ſeru'd curiouſly, ſit downe & eate your meate with leaſure, there we muſt be glad to take it ſtanding, & without either ſalt, cloath, or trencher, and ſay we are befriended too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh, that giues a Citizen a better appetite then his Garden.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: So ſay I Father, me thinkes it does me moſt good whē I take it ſtanding, I know not how all womens mindes are:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith I thinke they are al of thy minde for that thing, how now Falſlight?

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: I haue deſcri'd my fellow Short-yard, alias Blaſtfield, at hand with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh my ſweete Short-yard!—Daughter, get you vp to your Virginalls: by your leaue Miſtris Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why I hope I may ſitith ſhop, may I not?

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: That you may, and welcome ſweete hony-thye, but not at this ſeaſon, there's a Buck to be ſtrucke.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Well, ſince i'me ſo expreſly forbidden, ile watch aboue ith gallerie, but ile ſee your knauerie.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Be you preparde as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: You neare feard me:

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Oh that ſweete, neate, comely, proper, delicate parcell of land, like a fine Gentlewoman ith waſte: not ſo great as prettie, prettie: the Trees in Summer whiſtling, the ſiluer waters by the Bankes harmoniouſlye gliding, I ſhould haue beene a Scholler, an excellent place for a ſtudent: fit for my Sonne that lately commenc'd at Cambridge, whom now I haue plac'd at Innes of Court: Thus wee that ſildome get Landes honeſtly, muſt leaue our heires to inherit our knauerie: but whiſt, one turne about my ſhoppe and meete with e'm.

div.stage: Enter Maiſter Eaſie, with Short-yard, alias Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Is this it ſir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I, let me ſee, this is it: ſigne of three Knaues, tis it •

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Doe you heare ſir, what lacke you Gentlemen? ſee good Kerſies or broad cloathes heere, I pray come neere —Maiſter Blaſtfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I thought you would know me anon.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p:
You'r exceeding welcome to Towne ſir, your worſhip muſt pardon me, tis alwaies miſtie weather in our ſhops heere: we are a Nation the Sunne • ere ſhines vpon,—Came
this Gentleman with you?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O ſalute him fairely, hee's a kinde Gentleman, a verie in ward of mine.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Then I crye you mercy ſir, y'are eſpecially welcome.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: I returne you thankes ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But how ſhall I doe for you now Maiſter Blaſtfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It is my greateſt affliction at this inſtant, I am not able to furniſh you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How maiſter Quomodo, pray ſay not ſo, ſl'ud you vndoe me then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Vpon my Religion Maiſter Blaſtfield, bonds lye forfeete in my hands, I expect the receite of a thouſand euerie houre, and cannot yet ſet eye of a penny.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's ſtrange me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis mine owne pittie that plots againſt me Maiſter Blaſtfield, they knowe I haue no conſcience to take the for feture, and that makes em ſo bould with my mercie.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: I am ſorry for this.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Neuer the leſſe, if I might intreate your delay but the age of three daies to expreſſe my ſorrow now, I would double the ſumme, and ſupply you with foure or fiue hundred.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Let me ſee,—three daies.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I good ſir, and it may be poſſible.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Doe you heare Maiſter Blaſtfield,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: You knowe i'ue alreadie enuited all the Gallants to ſup with me to night.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's true yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: T will be my euerlaſting ſhame, if I haue no monye to maintaine my bountie.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I nere thought vpon that—I look't ſtill when that ſhould come from him, wee haue ſtrickly examined our expences, it muſt not be three daies Maiſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: No the • 'me afraide twill be my griefe ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Maiſter Blaſtfield, ile tell you what you may doe now.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What good ſweete bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Send to Maſter Goome, or Maſter Profit, the Mercer and Goldſmith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Maſſe that was well remembred of thee—I perceyue the Trout will bee a little troubleſome ere hee bee catcht—Boy. 〈…〉
Boy▪ Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Runne to Maſter Goome, or Maſter Profite, and carrie my preſent occaſion of money to em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I runne ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Me thinks Maiſter Blaſtfield, you might eaſily attaine to the ſatisfaction of 3. dayes, heer's a Gentleman your friend I dare ſay will ſee you ſufficiently poſſeſt till then.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Not I ſir, by no meanes: maſter Blaſtfield knowes I'me further in want then himſelfe, my hope reſts all vpon him, it ſtands vpon the loſſe of my credit to Night, if I walke without money.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why maiſter Quomodo, what a fruitleſſe Motion haue you put forth, you might wel • aſſure your ſelfe this gentleman had it not if I wanted it: why our purſes are brothers we deſire but equall fortunes: in a word w'are man and wife, they can but lie together, and ſo doe we.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: As nere as can be yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to ſay truth, tis more for the continuing of this Gentlemans credit in Towne then any incitement from mine owne want only, that I cou • t to be ſo immediatly furniſh • — you ſhall heare him confeſſe as much himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Tis moſt certaine maſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Oh here comes the Boy now: How now Boy, what ſayes maiſter Goome, or maſter Profit?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, thei'r both walke foorth this froſtie morning to Brainford, to ſee a Nurſe-childe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A Baſtard be it, ſpite and ſhame.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay, neuer vex your ſelfe ſweet maſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Bewitcht I thinke.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Doe you heare ſir? you can perſwade with him.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: A little ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
Rather then he ſhould be altogither deſtitute, or be
too much a vexation to himſelfe, he ſhall take vp a commoditie of cloath of me tell him.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why la! by my troth t' was kindly ſpoken.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds worth vpon my Religion ſay.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So diſaſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay, maiſter Blaſtfield, you doe not heare what maſter Quomodo ſaid ſince, like an honeſt true Citizen yfaith: rather then you ſhould grow diſeaſde vpon't, you ſhall take vp a commoditie of two hundred pounds • orth of cloath.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The mealie Moth conſume it, would hee hame turne Pedler now? what ſhould I doe with cloath?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee's a verie wilfull Gentleman at this Time yfaith: he knowes as well what to doe with it, as I my ſelfe Iwis: ther's no Merchant in Town but will be greedy vpon't, and pay downe mony vpo'th naile, the'l diſpatch it ouer to Middle-borrow preſently, and raiſe double commoditie by exchange, if not, you know tis Tearme-time, and Michaelmas Tearm too, the Drapers harueſt, for footcloaths, riding ſuts, walking ſuits, chamber gownes, and hall gownes.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay, Ile ſay that, it comes in as fit a time as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take me with you agen ere you go ſir, I offer him no traſh 〈◊〉 him, but preſent mony, ſay, where I know ſome Gentlemen in towne ha beene glad, and are glad at this time, to take vp commodities in Hawks hoods, and browne paper.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Oh horrible, are there ſuch fool • s in towne?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I offer him no traſh tell him, vpon my Religion you may ſay,—Now my ſweet Shortyand,—now the hungry fiſh begins to nibble: one end of the worme is in his mouth yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why ſtand I here (as late our graceleſſe Dames
That found no eyes) to ſee that Gentleman

Al • ue in ſtate and cred ••
〈◊〉
Helpe to rip vp himſelfe do's all he can,
Why am I wife to him that is no man?
I ſuffer in that Gentlemans confuſion.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay be perſwaded in that maſter Blaſtfield tis readie money at, the 〈◊〉 beſide, the 〈◊〉 and all falls in as pa • as can be 〈◊〉 helpe it.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well Maiſter Eaſie, none but you could haue perſwaded me to that, come, would you would diſpatch then Maiſter Quomodo, where's this cloath?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Full and whole within, all of this peece of my Religion Maiſter Blaſtfield, feel't, nay feel't and ſpare not, Gentlemen! your fingers and your iudgement.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Clothe's good.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: By my tro • h exceeding good cloath, a good wale t'as,

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falſlight.

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: I'me neere out 'athe ſhop ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Go, call in a Porter preſently to carrie away the cloath with the Starre marke, whither will you pleaſe to haue it carryed Maiſter Blaſtfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Faith to Maiſter Beggar-land, hee's the onely Marchant now: or his Brother Maiſter Stilliard-downe, there's little difference.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Y'aue hapned vpon the money men ſir, they and ſome of their Bretheren I can tell you, will not ſticke to offer thirtie thouſand pound to be curſt ſtill, great monyed men, their ſtockes lye in the Poores throates: but youle ſee me ſufficiently diſcharg'd Maiſter Blaſtfield ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You haue alwaies found me righteous in that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falſlight.

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You may bring a Scriuener along with you.

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: Ile remember that ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Haue you ſent for a Citizen Maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: No faith not yet—Boy!

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: What muſt you doe with a Citizen ſir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: A cuſtome they're bound to alate by the default ofeuill debters, no Citizen muſt lend money without two bee bound in the bond, the ſecond Man enters but for cuſtome ſake.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: No, and muſt hee needes be a Citizen?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Byth maſſe ſtay, ile learne that Maiſter Quomodo!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
Muſt the ſecond partie that enters into bond onely for faſhions ſake needs be a Citizen? what ſay you to this Gentleman
for one?

sp.speaker: Quomo.
sp.p: A laſſe ſir, you know hee's a meere ſtranger to me, I neither am ſure of his going or abiding, hee may Inne heere to Night, and ride away to morrow, (although I graunt the chiefe burden lyes vpon you) yet wee are bound to make choice of thoſe we know ſir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why hee's a Gentleman of a prettie liuing ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It may be ſo: yet vnder both your pardons I'de rather haue a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: I hope you wil not diſparadge me ſo? tis wel known I haue three hundred pound a yeare in Eſſex,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well ſaide, to him thy ſelfe, take him vp roundly.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: And how doubtfullie ſo ere you account of me, I doe not thinke but I might make my bond paſſe for a hundred pound'ith Citie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What alone ſir?

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Alone ſir: who ſaies ſo? perhaps ide ſend downe for a Tennant or too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, that's another caſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Another caſe let it be then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay, grow not into anger ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Not take me into a Bond, as good as you ſhall good man Gooſe-cap.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Wel Maiſter Blaſtfield, becauſe I wil not diſgrace the Gentleman, i'me content for once, but we muſt not make a practiſe on't.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: No ſir, now you would you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Cuds me, i'me vndone, hee's gone agen.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The Netts broke.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hold there deere Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Deny me that ſmall curtizie? s'foot a very Iew will not deny it me.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Now muſt I catch him warily.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: A ieſt indeede, not take me into a Bond quo they.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Maiſter Eaſie—Marke my words, if it ſtood not vppon the eternall loſſe of thy credit againſt Supper—

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Maſſe that's true.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The pawning of thy horſe for his owne Vittailes.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Right yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And thy vtter diſſolution amongeſt Gentlemen for e •• er.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Pox on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Quomodo ſhould hang, rot, ſtinke.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweete boy yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Drop Dam.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I forgot all this: what meant I to • wagger before I had money in my purſe? how do's maiſter Quomodo? is the Bond readie?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Come we muſt be friends, heer's my hand.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Giue it the Scriuener: here he comes.

sp.speaker: Duſt.
sp.p: Good day Maiſter Quomodo, good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: We muſt require a little ayde from your pen, good maſter Duſtbox.

sp.speaker: Duſt.
sp.p: What be the Gentlemens names that are bound ſir?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Maſter Iohn Blaſtfield Eſquireith wilde of Kent, and what doe they call your bed f • llowes name?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maiſter Richard Eaſie: you may eaſily hit on't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Maſter Richard Eaſie of Eſſex Gentleman, both bound to Epheſtian Quomodo Citizen and Draper of London: the ſumme two hundred pound. What Time doe you take maſter Blaſtfield for the payment?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I neuer paſſe my Month you know.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I know it ſir. October ſixteenth to day, ſixteenth of Nouember ſay.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Is it your cuſtome to returne ſo ſoone ſir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I neuer miſſe you.

div.stage: Enter Falſlight like a Porter, ſweating.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I am come for the reſt of the ſame price maſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Star-marke, this is it, are all the reſt gone?

sp.speaker: Fa • .
sp.p: Thei'r all at Maſter Stilyard downes by this time.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: How the poore raskall's all in a froth?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Puſh, their ordaind to ſweate for Gentlemen,— Porters backes and womens bellies beare vp the world.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Tis true yfaith, they beare men and money, and that's the world.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ye'aue found it ſir.

sp.speaker: Duſt.
sp.p: I'me readie to your hands Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come Maſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: It ſhall be yours I ſay.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay pray maſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I will not yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: What doe you meane ſir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I ſhould ſhew little bringing vp, to take the way of a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: By my troth you doe your ſelfe wrong tho maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not a whit ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: But to auoid ſtrife, you ſhall haue your will of mee for once.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let it be ſo I pray.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Now I begin to ſet one foote vppon the lande, mee thinkes I am felling of Trees alreadie, wee ſhall haue ſome Eſſex Loggs yet to keepe Chriſtmaſſe with, and that's a comfort.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Now is he quarting out the Executioner.
Strides ouer him: with his owne blood he writes:
I am no Dame that can endure ſuch ſights.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: So his right wing is cut, will not flie farre
Paſt the two Cittie hazards, Poultrie, and Woodſtreete.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: How like you my Roman hand yfaith?

sp.speaker: Duſt.
sp.p: Exceeding well ſir, but that you reſt too much vpon your R. and make your eaſe too little.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Ile mend that preſently.

sp.speaker: Duſt.
sp.p: Nay tis done now, paſt mending: you both deliuer this to maiſter Quomodo as your deede?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We doe ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Would the Coyne would come away now, we haue deſeru'd for't

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: By your leaue a little Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter? ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p:
As faſt as I can ſir—All the cloathes come backe a •
gen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What's the newes?

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: The paſſage to Middle borrow is ſtopt, and therefore neither Maiſter Still yard-downe, nor Maiſter Beggerland, nor any other Merchāt wil deliuer preſent money vppon't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why what hard lucke haue you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why Maiſter Blaſtfield?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Piſh—

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: You'r ſo diſcontented too preſently, a man cannot tell how to ſpeake to you?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why what would you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: We muſt make ſome what on't now ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I where? how? the beſt is it lyes all vppon my necke, Maiſter Quomodo, can you help me to any money fort? ſpeak

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Troth Maiſter Blaſtfield, ſince my ſelfe is ſo vnfurniſht, I knowe not the meanes how, there's one 'ith ſtreete a new ſetter vp, if any lay out money vppon't twill be he.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: His name:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Maſter Idem—but you know we cannot giue but greatly to your loſſe, becauſe we gaine and liue by't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Sfoo't will he giue any thing.

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: I, ſtand vppon that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Will he giue any thing?—the Brokers will giue nothing? to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falſlight.

sp.speaker: Falſl.
sp.p: Ouer your head ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Deſire Maiſter Idem to come preſently and looke vppo'th cloath.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What if hee ſhould offer but a hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: If he want twentie on't lets take it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: Maiſter Quomodo we wil haue foure or fiue hundred pound for you of his owne within three or foure daies.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tis true, he ſaide ſo indeede.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Is That your wife maiſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: That's ſhee, little Tomazin?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Vnder your leaue ſir, ile ſhow my ſelfe a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Doe, and welcome Maiſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: I haue commiſſion for what I doe Lady from your Husband.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You may haue a ſtronger commiſſion for the next, an't pleaſe you, that's from my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: You teach me the beſt law Lady.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Beſhrew my blood, a proper, ſpringfull, and a ſweet Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: My Sonne: Sim Quomodo? heere's more worke for you Maiſter Eaſie, you muſt ſalute him too, for hee's like to be heire of thy land I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Vim, vitam, ſprin
que ſalutem.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He ſhowes you there he was a Cambridge man ſir, but now hee's a Templer, ha's he not good grace to make a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: A very good grace to make a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: For indeede he ha's no grace at all.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Some gaue me counſell to make him a Diuine.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Fye, fie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But ſome of our liuerie thinke it an vnfit thing, that our owne Sonnes ſhould tell vs of our vices: others, to make him a Phiſitian, but then being my heyre, i'me afraide hee would make me away: now a Lawyer thei'r all willing too, becauſe tis good for our trade and encreaſeth, the number of Cloath-gownes, and indeede tis the fitteſt for a Citizens Sonne, for our word is, what doe yee lacke? and their word is what doe you giue.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Exceeding propper.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Maiſter Idem welcome.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I haue ſeene the cloath ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Verie well.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I am but a yong ſetter vp, the vttermoſt I dare ventture vppon 'tis three-ſcore pound.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Falſt.
sp.p: If it be for me, ſo, I am for it: if not, you haue your doth and I haue my money.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Nay, pray maiſter Blaſtfield refuſe not his kinde offer.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: A bargaine then maiſter Idem, clap hands—hee's finely cheated: come, let's all to the next Tauerne and ſee the money paide.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I follow you Gentlemen, take my Sonne along with you.

Now to my keyes: •• me Maiſter Idem, hee muſt fetch the money, firſt haue I caught him in a bond for two hundred pound, and my two hundred poundes worth a doath agen for three-ſcore pound: admire me all you ſtudyents at Innes for couſenage.

div.head: Incipit Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Let • es pa • der, Helgill, the Caūtrie wench comming in with a new 〈◊〉 Gawne dreſt Gentlewoman like, the Taylor p • intes it, and a Tyrewomen buſie about her head.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: You talke of an alteration, heer's the thing it ſelfe, what baſe birthe does not rayment make glorious? and what glorious birthes do not • agges make infamous? why ſhould not a woman confeſſe what ſhe is now? fince the fineſt are but deluding ſhadowes, begot betweene Tyr •• omen and Taylors? for inſtance, beholde their Parents.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Say what you wil, this wire becomes you beſt, how ſay you Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I promiſe you tis a wire would draw mee from my worke ſeauen daies a weeke.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why doe you worke a ſundaies Taylor?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Hardeſt of al a Sundaie, becauſe we are moſt forbidden

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Troth and ſo doe moſte of vs women, the better day the better deede we thinke.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Excellēt exceeding yfaith, a narrow card wyer ſets out a cheeke ſo fat and ſo full, and if you be rulde by me, you ſhal weare your hayre ſtill like a Mock-face behinde, tis ſuch an Italian world, many men knowe not Before from Behinde.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: How like you the ſitting of this gowne now Miſtris Comings?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: It ſits at meruailous good Eaſe, and comely diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Who would thinke now this fine Sophiſticated ſqual came out of the Boſome of a Barne, and the loynes of a Haytoſſer.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Out you ſawcie peſtiferous Pander, I ſcorne that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Excellent, already the true phraſe and ſtile of a ſtrumpet, ſtay, a little more of the red, and then I take my leaue of your Cheeke for foure & twenty houres—Doe you not thinke it impoſſible that her owne Father ſhould know her now, if he ſaw her?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why I thinke no leſſe, how can he knowe me, when I ſcarce knowe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Helg:
sp.p: Tis right.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: But ſo well you lay waite for a man for me.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: I proteſt I haue beſtowed much labour about it, and in fit Time, good newes I hope.

div.stage: Enter one bringing in her Father in diſguiſe to ſerue her.
div.p: 1 Iu'e found one yet at laſt, in whoſe preferment I hope to reape credit.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is that the fellowe?
1 Lady it is.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Art thou willing to ſerue me fellow?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: So pleaſe you, he that ha's not the heart to ſerue ſuch a Miſtris as your beautifull ſelfe, deſerues to be honoured for a foole, or Knighted for a Coward.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: There's to many of them alreadie.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Twere ſinne then to raiſe the number.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Well, weele trie both our likings for a month, and then eyther proceede, or let fall the ſuite.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Be it as you haue ſpoke, but tis my hope A longer Tearme.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No truely, our Tearme endes once a month, wee ſhould get more then the Lawyers, for they haue but foure Tearmes a yeare, and wee haue twelue, & that makes e'm run ſo faſt to vs in the Vacation.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A miſtris of of a choice beauty, amongſt ſuch imperfect creatures I ha not ſeene a perfecter: I ſhould haue reckoned the fortunes of my Daughter amongſt the happieſt, had ſhe lighted into ſuch a ſeruice, whereas now I reſt doubt full, whome or where ſhe ſerues.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: There's for your bodily aduice Taylor, and theres for your head-counſell, and I diſcharge you both till to morrowe morning agen.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: At which time our neateſt Attendance.

sp.speaker: Coin.
sp.p: I pray haue an eſpeciall care howſoeuer you ſtand or lye, that nothing fall vppon your haire to batter your wire.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I warrant you for that—which Gowne becomes me beſt now, the purple Sattin or this?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: If my opinion might rule ouer you—

div.stage: Enter Lethe with Rerage and Salewood.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Come gallants, ile bring you to a Beauty ſhal ſtricke your eyes into your hearts, what you ſee you ſhall deſire, yet neuer enioy.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And that's a Villanous torment.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: And is ſhe but your vnderput Maiſter Lethe?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No more of my credit, and a Gentlewoman of a great houſe, Noble parentage, vnmatchable Education, my plain Pung. I may, grace her with the name of a Curtizan, a Backſlider, a Proſtitution, or ſuch a Toy, but when all comes • o al tis but a plaine Pung, looke you Gentlemen, that's ſhe, beholde her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Oh my beloued ſtrayer! I conſume in thy abſence.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: La you now—you ſhall not ſay ile be proud to you Gentlemen, I giue you leaue to ſalute her▪ I me afraide of nothing now, but that ſheele vtterlie diſgrace e'm, turn taile to e'm, and place their kiſſes behinde her, no by my faith, ſhe deceiues me, by my troth ſha's kiſt am both with her lips: I thanke you for that muſick maiſters, ſli'd they both court her at once, and ſee if ſhe ha not the wit to ſtand ſtill and let e'm: I thinke if two men were brewde into one, there is that woman would drink e'm vp both.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: A Cockſcombe, he a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He ſaies he ha's a place there.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: So ha's the Foole a better place then he, and can come where he dare not ſhow his head.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Nay, he are you me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I proteſt you were the laſt man we ſpoke on, we're a little buſie yet, pray ſtay there a while, weele come to you preſently.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: This is good yfaith, indure this and be a ſlaue foreuer, ſince you neither ſauour of good breeding nor bringing vp, Ile ſlice your hamſtrings but ile make you ſhow mannerly—pox on you, leaue courting, I ha not the heart to hurt an Engliſhman yfaith, or elſe—

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: What elſe?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Prethee lets be merrie, nothing elſe—heere, fetch ſome wine.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let my Seruant goe for't.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your's, which is he?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This ſir, but I ſcarce like my Miſtris now: the loynes can nere be ſafe where the Flyes be ſo buſie— Witte by experience bought foyles wit at Schoole: Who proues a deeper knaue then a Spent foole, I am gone for your worſhips wine ſir.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Sir, you put vp too much indignitie, bring company to cut your owne throate, the fire is not yet ſo hot, that you neede two Screenes before it, tis but new kindled yet, if twere riſſe to a flame, I could not blame you thē to put others before you but alaſſe all the heate yet is comfortable a cherriſher, not a defacer.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prethe let e'm alone, theile bee aſham'd o • t anon I troe, if they haue any grace in 'em.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Ide faine haue him quarrell, fight, and be aſſuredlye kild, that I might beg his place: for there's nere a one voide yet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Youle make him mad anon.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Tis to that end.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Yet at laſt, Maiſter Quomodo is as firme as his promiſe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Did I not tell you ſtill he would.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let me ſee, I am ſeauen hundred pound in bond now to the Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay y'are no leſſe Maiſter Blaſtfield, looke too't, by my troth, I muſt needes confeſſe ſir, you ha bene vncommonly kinde to me, ſince I ha beene in Towne, but maiſter Alſup ſhall know on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's my Ambition ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir. Stay, this is Lethes haunt, ſee, we haue catcht him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maiſter Blaſtfield and Maiſter Eaſie, y'are kinde Gentlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is that the beauty you famde ſo?

sp.speaker: Leeh.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Who be thoſe ſo induſtrious about her?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Rerage and Salewood: • le tell you the vnmannerlyeſt tricke of e'm, that euer you heard in your life.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Prethee whats that?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I • nuyfed e'm hyther to looke vpon her, brought e'm along with me, gaue e'm leaue to ſalute her in kindnes, what doe they but moſte ſawcilie fall in loue with her, verye impudently court her for themſelues, and like two craftye Atturneyes, finding a hole in my leaſe, goe about to defeate me of my right.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ha they ſo little conſcience?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The moſte vnciuilſt part that you haue ſeene, I know theile be ſorry for't when they haue done, for ther's no man but giues a ſigh after his ſin of women, I knowe it by my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You parcell of a rude, ſawcie and vnmannerly nation.

sp.speaker: Lethe.
sp.p: One good thing in him, heele tell e'm ont roundly.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Cannot a Gentleman purchaſe a little fire to thawe his appetite by, but muſt you that haue beene dayly ſindg'd in the flame, be as greedy to beguile him on't? how can it appeare in you but maliciouſly, and that you goe about to engroſſe hell to your ſelues? he auen forbid, that you ſhould not ſuffer a ſtranger to come in, the Deuill himſelfe is not ſo vnmannerly, I doe not thinke but ſome of them rather will be wiſe enough to beg▪ Offices there before you, and keepe you out, marry all the ſpite will bee they cannot ſell e'm agen.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Come, are you not to blame—not to giue place?— To vs I meane—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A worſe and a worſe diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, you wrong vs both then, ſtand from me, I proteſt ile draw my ſiluer Bodkin vpon you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Clubs, clubs,—Gentlemen ſtand vppon your Guard.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman muſt ſwagger a little now and then I perceiue, there would bee no ciuilitie in her Chamber elſe, though it be my hard fortune to haue my keeper there a coward, the thing that's kept is a Gentlewoman borne.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to conclude a Coward, infallible of your ſide, why doe you thinke yfaith I tooke you to be a Coward? doe I thinke youle turne your backe to anye man liuing? youle be whipt firſt.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: And then indeede ſhe turnes her backe to ſome man liuing.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But that man ſhowes himſelfe a Knaue, for he dares not ſhowe his owne face when hee does it, for ſome of the common Counſell in Henry the eights daies thought it modeſtie at that time, that one Vizzard ſhould looke vppon another.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Twas honeſtly conſidered of e'm yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what peece of ſtuffe comes heere?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Now ſome good newes yet to recouer my Repute, and grace me in this company; Gentlemen, are we friendes among our ſelues?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Vinited.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Then heere comes Reuiſh to confirme our Amitie— Wag▪ taile, ſalute • hem all they are friendes.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Then ſauing my quarrell to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Toe's all

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Now be ſhrowe your hearts, and you doe not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To ſweete Maiſter Lethe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let it flow this way deere Maiſter Blaſtfield, Gentlemen to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This Re • iſh wine is like the ſcowring-ſticke to a gun, it makes the Barrell cleere: it ha's an excelent vertue, it keepes all the Sinckes in man and womans bodie ſweete in Iune and Iuly, and to ſay truth, if Ditches were not caſt once a yeare, and Drabs once a Month, there would be no abiding i'th Cittie.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ile make you priuie to a letter I ſent.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A letter comes well after priuie, it makes amends.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: There's one Quomodo▪ a Drapers Daughter in towne whome for her happie portion I wealthily affect.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And not for loue? this makes for me his Riuall, beare witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The Father does elect me for the man, The Daughter ſayes the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Yes all but for the mother, ſhee's my ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Birlady and the Mother is a peſtilent, wilfull, troubleſome ſickneſſe I can tell you, if ſhe light vpon you handſomlye.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I finde it ſo: ſhe for a ſtranger pleades: Whoſe name I ha not learn'd.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And ene now he cald me by it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now as my letter tolde her, ſince onely her conſent kept aloofe of, what might I thinke on't, but that ſhe meerely dooted vpon me herſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Very aſſuredly.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: This makes ſtill for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Did you let it goe ſo yfaith?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You may beleeue it ſir, now what ſayes her anſwere?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I, her anſwere.

sp.speaker: Gruil.
sp.p: She ſaies you'r a baſe proud knaue, and like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay, heare out hir anſwere, or there's no goodneſſe in you.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: You ha forgot ſhe ſaies in what pickle your worſhip came vp, and brought two of your friendes to giue their wordes for a ſute of greene Kerſye.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Drudge, peace, or—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Show your ſelfe a Gentleman, ſhe had the patience to reade your letter which was as bad as this can be, what will ſhe thinke on't, not heare her anſwere? ſpeake, good his drudge.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And as for hir Daughter, ſhee hopes ſheele be rulde by her in time, and not be carryed away with a caſt of Manchets, a bottle of Wine, and a Cuſtard, which once made her Daughter ſicke, becauſe you came by it with a bad conſcience.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, i'me all in a ſweate.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's verie wholſome for your body, nay you muſt keepe in your armes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Then ſhe demaunded of me whether I was your worſhips Ant or no?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Out, out, out, Gru. Alaſſe ſaide I, I am a poore drudge of his.

div.p: Faith and thou wert his Mother (quoth ſhe) heed make thee his Dru dge I warrant him—
Marry out vpon him (quoth I) an't like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Horror, horror, i'me ſmother'd, let me goe, torment me not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you loue me, lets follow him Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I count a hundred pound wel ſpent to perſue a good ieſt Maiſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: By my troth I begin to beare that minde too.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Well ſaide yfaith, hang money-good ieſts are worth ſiluer at all times.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: They'r worth golde Maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Doe you deceiue me ſo? are you toward marriage yfaith Maſter Lethe it ſhall goe hard but ile forbid the Banes, ile ſend a meſſēger into your bones, another into your purſſe but ile doo't.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Thou faire and wicked Creature, ſteept in Arte,
Beautious and freſh, the ſoule the fowleſt part.
A common Filth, is like a Houſe poſſeſt,
Where if not ſpoild, youle come out fraide at leaſt,
This ſeruice likes not me, though I reſt poore,
I hate the baſeſt vſe to ſcreene a whore.
The humaine ſtroke nere made him, hee that can
Be Bawde to Woman, neuer leapt from man.
Some monſter wunne his Mother,
I wiſht my poore childe hether, doubled wrong,
A month and ſuch, a miſtris were too long,
Yet heere a while in others liues ile ſee,
How former follyes, did appeare in me.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Where left you Maiſter Blaſtfield your maiſter, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
