sp.p: An houre ſince I left him in Paules ſir—but youle not finde him the ſame man agen next time you meete him.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Methinks I haue noe beeing without his companie tis ſo full of kindenes and delight, I holde him to be the onely Companyon in earth.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, as Companions goe now adaies that helpe to ſpend a mans money.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: So full of nimble wit, various diſcourſe, praegnant apprehenſion, and vncommon entertainment, hee might keepe Company with any Lord for his grace.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, with any Lord that were paſt it.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p:
And ſuch a good free hearted honeſt, affable kinde of
Gentleman: Come Boy a heauineſſe will poſſeſſe me till I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But youle finde your ſelfe heauyer then, by a ſeauen hundred pound weight,—Alaſſe poore Birds that cannot keepe the ſweete Countrie, where they ſlye at pleaſure, but muſt needes come to London to haue their wings clipt, and are faine to goe hopping home agen.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falſlight like a Sarieant and a Yeoman to arreſt Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So, No man is ſo impudent to denye that— Spirits can change their ſhapes, and ſooneſt of all into Serjeants: becauſe they are Cooſen Germans to ſpirits, for there's but two kinde of arreſts till Doomeſ-day, the Deuill for the ſoule, the Serjeant for the body, but afterward the deuill arreſts bodye and ſoule Serjeant & all, if they be knaues ſtill, and deſerue it▪ now my yeoman • aſlight.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I Attend you good Serjant Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: No more maiſter Blaſtfield now—poore Eaſie hardly be ſet.

sp.speaker: Falſ • .
sp.p: But how if he ſhould goe to priſon, weere in a madde ſtate then, being not Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Neuer let •• come neere thy belee • e that heele take priſon, or ſtand out in lawe, knowing the debt to be due, but ſtill expect the preſence of Maiſter Blaſtfield, kinde M. Blaſtfield, worſhipfull M Blaſtfield—and at the laſt—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maiſter Shortyard, maiſter Falſlight.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Boy: a warning-piece,—ſee where he comes.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Is not in paules.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is not farre off ſure ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: When was his hovre ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Two ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why two ha's ſtrucke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No ſir, they are now a ſtriking.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maiſter Richard Eaſie of Eſſex we arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alaſſe a Surgeon, hee's hurt ith ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Deliuer your weapons quietly ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Y'are arreſted at the ſuite of M. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Maiſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How ſtrange you make it, you'r a landed Gentleman ſir, I knew tis but a triſſe, a bond of ſeauen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: La, I knowe you had miſtooke, you ſhould arreſt One Maiſter Blaſtfield, tis his bond, his debt.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is not your name there?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: True, for faſhions ſake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why and tis for faſhions ſake that we arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nay, & it be no more, I yeelde to that: I know Maiſter Blaſtfield wil ſee me take no iniurie as long as i'me in towne, for Maiſter Alſups ſake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Whoſe that Sir?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: An honeſt Gentleman in Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Oh, In Eſſex! I thought you had beene in London, where now your buſines lyes, honeſtye from Eſſex will be a great while a comming ſir, you ſhould looke out an honeſt paire of Cittizens.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Alaſſe ſir, I knowe not where to finde e'm.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: No, there's enow in Towne.

sp.speaker: Eaſ • .
sp.p: I know not one by my troth, I am a meere ſtranger for theſe partes, Maiſter Quomodo is all, and the honeſteſt that I knowe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To him then lets ſet forward:—Yeoman Spiderman, caſtan eye about for Maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Boy—Alaſſe the poore boy was frighted away at firſt.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Can you blame him ſir—we that dayly fray away Knight's, may fright away Boyes I hope.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ha? haue they him ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As ſure as—

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: The land's mine, thats ſure enough boy.
Let me aduaunce thee knaue, and giue thee a kiſſe,
My pl • t's ſo firme I dare it now to miſſe.
Now ſhall I be diuulgde a landed man,
Throughout the liuerie:—one points, another whiſpers,
A third frets inwardly: let him fret and hang,
Eſpecially his enuie I ſhall haue,
That would be faine, yet cannot be a knaue,
Like an olde leather girt in furde Gowne,
Whoſe minde ſtands ſtiffe but his performance downe.
Now come my golden daies in:—whither is the worſhipfull
maſter Quomodo, and his faire Bedfellow rid forth,
To his land in Eſſex? whence comes thoſe goodly loade of
Logs? from his land in Eſſex? where growes this pleaſant
fruit, ſayes one Citizens wife in the rowe; at maiſter Quomodos
Orchard in Eſſex; oh, oh, do's it ſo, I thanke you for
that good newes yfaith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here they come with him ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Grant mee patience in my ioyes, that being ſo great I run not mad with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Bleſſe maiſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now Serjeants? who ha you brought me here, maſter Eaſie?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why la you now Serjeants, did I not tell you you mistooke?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Did you not heare me ſay. I had rather ha had maſter Blaſtfield, the more ſufficient man a great deale?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Verie true ſir,—but this Gentleman lighting into our hands firſt—

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why did you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Wee thought good to make vſe of that oportunitie, and hold him faſt.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You did well in that I muſt needes ſay, for your owne ſecurities, but twas not my minde maſter Eaſie to haue you firſt, you muſt needes thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I dare ſweare that maſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But ſince you are come to me, I haue no reaſon to refuſe you, I ſhould ſhow little manners in that ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p:
But I hope you ſpake not in that ſence ſir, to impoſe
the bond vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: By my troth that's my meaning ſir, you ſhall finde mee an honeſt man, you ſee I meane what I ſay, is not the day paſt, the money vntendred, you'd ha me liue vprightly maiſter Eaſie?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why ſir, you know maiſter Blaſtfield is the man.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why ſir, I know maſter Blaſtfield is the man, but is he any more then one man? two entred into bond to mee, or I'me fowly coozn'd.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: You know my entrance was but for faſhion ſake.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why, ile a gree to you, you'l grant tis the faſhion likewiſe when the Bond's due to haue the money paid agen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So we told him ſir, and that it lay in your worſhips curtezie to arreſt which you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Marie do's it ſir, theſe fellowes know the law,— beſide, you offred yourſelf into Bond to me you know, when I had no ſtomake to you, now beſhrew your heart for your labour, I might ha had a good ſubſtantiall Citizen, that would ha paid the ſumme roundly, altho I think you ſufficient enough for ſeauen hundred pound, beſide the forfeyture, I would be loath to diſgrace you ſo much before Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: If you would hathe pacience ſir, I doe not thinke but maſter Blaſefield is at Carriers to receiue the money.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He wil proue the honeſter man then, & you the better diſcharged, I wonder he ſhould breake with me, t'was neuer his practiſe, you muſt not bee angry with mee now, tho you were ſomewhat hot when you entred into Bond, you may eaſily go in angerly, but you cannot come out ſo.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: No, the Diuels in't for that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Do you heere ſir, a my troth we pittie you, ha you any ſtore of Crownes about you?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Faith a poore ſtore, yet they ſhall be at their ſeruice that will ſtriue to doe me good,—we were both drunke laſt night, and • eer thought vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I muſt tell you this, you haue fell in to the hands of a moſt mercileſſe deuourer, the verie gul athe citie, ſhould you offer him mony, Goods or lands now, hee'd rather haue your bodie in priſon, hee's a ſuch a nature. Eaſ. Priſon w'are vndon then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hee's a ſuch a nature, looke?—Let him owe any man a ſpite • what's his courſe: he will lend him mony to day, a purpoſe to reſt him tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Defend me?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Has at leaſt ſixteene at this inſtant proceeded in both the Counters: ſome batchler, ſome maſters, ſome doctors of captiuitie of 20. years ſtanding and he deſires nothing more then impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Would Ma. Blaſtfield would come away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I, then things would not bee as they are—what will you ſay to vs if wee procure you two ſubſtantiall ſubſidie Cittizens to baile you ſpite on's heart, and ſet you at libertie to finde out maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Serjeant! here, take all, ile be deare to you, doe but performe it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Much.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Inough ſweet Serjeant, I hope I vnderſtand thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I loue to preuent the malice of ſuch a raſcall, perhaps you might find maiſter Blaſtfield to night.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why, we lie together man, there's the ieſt on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Fie.—and youle ſeeke to ſecure your baile, becauſe they will be two Cittizens of good account, you muſt doe that for your credit ſake.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Ile be bound to ſaue them harmeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A pox on him, you cut his throte then,—no words.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: What's it you require me maiſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You know that before this time I hope ſir, preſent money, or preſent impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: We nere had money of you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You had commodities, an't pleaſe you

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Well, may I not craue ſo much libertie vpō my word, to ſeeke out maiſter Blaſtfield?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Yes, and you would not laugh at me: wee are ſometimes Gulls to Gentlemen▪ I thanke 'em; but Gentlemen are neuer Gulls to vs, I commend 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Vnder your leaue maſter Quomodo, the Gentleman craues the furtherance of an houre, and it ſorts well with our
occaſion at this time, hauing a little vrgent buſines at Guildhall, at which minute weele returne, and ſee what agreement is made.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take him along with you Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I'me vndone then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hee's your priſoner; and being ſafe in your houſe at your owne diſpoſing, you cannot denie him ſuch a requeſt: beſide, he hath a little faith in Ma. Blaſtfields comming ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Let me not be too long delaid I charge you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Not an houre yfaith ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O maiſter Eaſie, of all men liuing I neuer dream▪ you would ha done me this iniurie: make me would my credite, faile in my commodities, ring my ſtate into ſuſpition: for the breaking of your day to me, has broken my day to others.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: You tell me of that ſtill, which is no fault of mine maſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh whats a man but his honeſtie maſter Eaſie, and thats a fault amongſt moſt of vs all,—Marke but this note, Ile giue you good counſell now,—as often as you giue your name to a bond, you muſt think you chriſten a child, and take the charge on't too: for as the one, the bigger it growes the more coſt it requires: ſo the other the longer it lies, the more charges it puts you too, onely heer's the difference a childe muſt bee broke, and a bond muſt not, the more you breake children, the more you keep 'em vnder: but the more you breake bondes, the more theyle leape in your face, and therefore, to conclude, I would neuer vndertake to bee Goſſip to that bond which I would not ſee well brought vp.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir?—Ile thinke vpon your counſaile hereafter for't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ah foole, thou ſhouldeſt neere ha taſted ſuch witte but that I know tis too late.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The more I grieue:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: To put all this into the compaſſe of a litle hoop Ring
Make this account, come better dayes or worſe,
So many bonds abroad, ſo many boyes at nurſe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p:
A good medicine for a ſhort memorie:—but ſince,
you haue entred ſo farre, whoſe children are deſperate depts I pray?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith they are like the of-ſprings of ſtolne luſt, put to the hoſpital, their fathers are not to be found, they are either too far abroad, or too cloſe within, and thus for your memories ſake.
sp.l: The deſperate Debter hence deriues his name,
One that has neither money, land nor fame,
All that he makes, proue Beſtards, and not Bonds,
But ſuch as yours, at firſt are horn • to lands.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: But all that I beget heereafter • le ſo one diſinherit Maiſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: In the meane time heeres a ſhrewd knaue will diſinherit you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Well, to put you out of all doubt Maiſter Quomodo, ile not truſt to your curtezie, I ha ſent for bayle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How? y'aue co • z • ed me there y • aith.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Since the worſt comes to the worſt, I haue thoſe friends 'ith Cittie, I hope that will not ſuffer me to lye for ſeauen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: And you tolde me you had no friendes heere at all, how ſhould a man truſt you now?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: That was but to trie your Curteſie M. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How vncōſcionably he gulls himſelf—they muſt be wealthye ſubſidie-men ſir, at leaſt fortye pound 'ith Kings Bookes I can tell you, that doe ſuch a feate for you.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falſlight, like wealthy Cittizens in Sattin ſutes.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Heere they come what ſo ere they are.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Berlady Aldermans Deputies, I am verie ſorrye for you ſir, I cannot refuſe ſuch men.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you the Gentleman in diſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: None more then my ſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee ſpeakes truer then he thinkes, for if he knew, The hearts that owe thoſe faces—a darke ſhop's good for ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: That was all ſir.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: And that's enough, for by that meanes' you haue made your ſelfe • able to the Bond, as well as that Baſefield

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Blaſtfield ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Oh 〈◊〉
• ou mercie tis Blaſtfield indeede.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: But vnder both your worſhips fauours I know where to finde him preſently.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's all your refuge.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Newes, good newes Maſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: What boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Maiſter Blaſtfield • y maiſter ha • receiued a tho 〈◊〉
pound, and will be at his lodging at ſupper.

sp.speaker: Eaſie.
sp.p: Happy • newes, heare you that Maiſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis enough for you to heare that, y'are the fortunate man ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Not now I beſeech your good worſhips.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentleman, what's your to • her name?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O Maiſter Eaſie—I would we could rather pleaſure you otherwiſe Maiſter Eaſie, you ſhould ſoone perceiue it, ile ſpeake a proud word we haue pittied more Gentlemen in diſtreſſe, then any two Cittizens within the freedome— but to be baile to ſea • en hundred pound action, is a matter of ſhroud weight.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Ile be bound to ſecure you.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: Tut, what's your bond ſir?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Bodye, goods, and Lands, immediately before Maſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Shall we venture once agen, that haue beene ſo often vndone by Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I haue no great ſtomacke too't, it will appeare in vs more pittie then wiſdome.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Why ſhould you ſay ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I like the Gentlemans face well, hee doe's not looke as if he would deceiue vs.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: O not I ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Come weele make a deſperate voyage once agen,
weele trye his honeſtie, and take his ſingle bond, of body Goods and Lands.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I dearely thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maiſter Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Shortyard.
sp.p: We haue tooke a Courſe to ſet your priſoner free.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worſhips are good baile you content me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come then, and be a witneſſe to a Re • ulliſance.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: With all my heart ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maiſter Eaſie, you muſt haue an eſpeciall care now to find out that Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I ſhall haue him at my lodging ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The 〈◊〉 will 〈…〉 you ſelſe, Maiſter Quomodo will come vpon vt, and 〈◊〉 you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I know that ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Well ſince I ſee you haue ſuch a good minde to bee honeſt
• e lea • e ſome greater 〈…〉 ſweate with you to finde him my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p:
H • are then my miſ • rie ends 〈…〉
A ſtrangers kindeneſſe oft exceedes a friends.

sp.l: Thou art deceiu • d thy miſerie but begins,
"To beguile goodnes, is the coare of ſins.
My loue is ſuch vnto • hee, that I die

As often as thou drink'ſt vp 〈◊〉
▪
Yet haue no meanes to warne thee from't, for hee
"That ſowes in Craft, doe's rape in Iealouſie.

sp.speaker: Rerrage.
sp.p: Now the letters made vp and all, it wants but the print of a ſ • ale, and away it goes to Maiſter Quomodo: Andrew Le • he is well whipt in't, his name ſtands in a white ſheete heere, and do • s pennance for him.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: You haue ſhame enough againſt him, if that be good.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Firſt as a contempt of that reuerend Ceremony, hee has in hand, to wit, marriage.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Why doe you ſay to wit marriage, when you knowe theres none will marrie that's wiſe.

sp.speaker: R • r.
sp.p: Had it not more neede then, to haue wit to put too't if it be growne to a • olly?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Y' • ue • un, ile giue't you.

sp.speaker: Rerag.
sp.p: Tis no thankes now,—but as I was ſaying: as a ſoule contempt to that ſacred ceremony, hee moſte audaciouſlye keepes a Drab in towne, and to be free from the interruption of blew Beadles, and other bawdy Officers, hee moſt politickly lodges her in a Conſtables houſe.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: That's a prettie point yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And ſo the wa • ch that ſhould fe • ch her out▪ are her chiefeſt guard to keepeher in.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: It muſt needes be for looke how the Conſtable playes his Conſcience, the watch-men will followe the ſuite.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why well then.

div.stage: Enter Eaſie with Shortyard like a Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: All night from me hee's hurt, hee's made away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Where ſhall we ſeeke him now? you leade me fayre
• aunt's ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Pray keepe a little patience ſir, I ſhall finde him at laſt you ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A Cittizen of my e • ſe and ſubſtance to walke ſo long a foote.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: You ſhould ha had my horſe but that he ha's eaten out his head ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How would you had me hold him by the tayle ſir then?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Manners forbid, tis no part of my meaning ſir,—oh heere's Maiſter Rerage, and Maiſter Salewood, now we ſhall heare of him preſently:—Gntlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Maiſter Eaſie, how fare you ſir?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Verye well in health, did you ſee Maiſter Blaſtfield this morning?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I was about to moue it to you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: We were all three in a minde then.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I ha not ſet eye on him theſe two daies.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wonder he keepes ſo long from vs yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I began to be ſicke.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Nothing in troth, but a great deſire I had to haue ſeene him.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wōder you ſhuld miſſe on't lately, you'r his bedfelow

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I lay alone to night yfaith,—I doe not know how, O here comes maſter Lethe, he can diſpatch me: Maſter Lethe!

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: What's your name ſir?—O crie you mercie maſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: When parted you from maiſter Blaſtfield ſir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Blaſtfield's an Aſſe, I haue ſought him theſe two dayes to beate him.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Your ſelfe all alone ſir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I, and three more.—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I am glad, I am where I am then, I perceiue twas time of all handes.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Content yfaith, let's trace him.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? haue you found him yet? neither? what's to be done now? ile venter my bodie no further for any Gentlemans pleaſure, I know not how ſoone I may be cald vppon, and now to ouer-heate my ſelfe.—

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Ime vndone.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This is you that ſlept with him, you can make fooles of vs, but ile turne you ouer to Quomodo fort.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Good ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ile preuent mine owne danger.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tho I loue Gentlemen well, I doe not meane to bee vndone for 'em.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Pray ſir, let mee requeſt you ſir, ſweete ſir, I beſeech you ſir.

div.head: Incipit quartus.
div.stage: Enter Quomodo, his diſguiſed ſpirits, after whom Eaſie followes hard.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Made fooles of vs! not to be found!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Do not vndoe me quite tho Ma Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Y'are verie welcome, maſter Eaſie, I ha nothing to ſay to you, ile not touch you, you may goe when you pleaſe,— I haue good baile here I thanke their worſhips.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay, or whom ſhall I beſeech▪

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentlemen, S'lid they were borne to vndo vs I think, but for my part, Ile make an oath before maiſter Qomodo here, nere to doe Gentlemen good while I liue.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Ile not be long behind you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Away; if you had any grace in you, you would bee aſhamed to looke vs ith face, ywis I wonder with what browe you can come amongſt vs, I ſhould ſeeke my fortunes fa • re enough if I were you, and neither returne to Eſſex, to bee a ſhame to my predeceſſors, nor remaine about London, to be a mocke to my ſucceſſors.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Subtle Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Here are his lands forfeyted to vs maſter Quomodo, and to auoyd the inconſcionable trouble of law, all the aſſi •
• ance he made to vs, we willingly reſigne to you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What ſhall I doe with Rubbiſh, giue me money: Tis for your worſhips to haue land, that keepe great houſes, I ſhould be hoyſted.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But maſter Quomodo, if you would but conceyue it aright, the land would fall fitter to you then to vs.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Curtzing about my land.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You haue a towardly ſonne and heyre as we heare.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I muſt needs ſay, he is a Templer indeed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We haue neither poſteritie in Towne nor hope for any abroad; we haue wiues, but the markes haue beene out of their mouths theſe twentie yeares, and as it appeares, they did little good when they were in: wee could not ſtande about it ſir, to g • t riches and children too▪ tis more then one man can doe. And I am of thoſe Citizens mindes that ſay, let our wi • es make ſhift for children and they will, they get none of vs; and I cannot thinke, but he that has both much wealth and many children, has had more helpes comming in then himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I am not a Bowe wide of your minde ſir.— And for the thriſtie and couetous hopes I haue in my ſonne and heyre Sim Qmomodo, that hee will neuer truſt his land in Waxe and Parchment as many Gentlemen haue done before him.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Al y-blow for me.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I will honeſtly diſcharge you, and recevue it in due forme and order of law, to ſtrengthen it for euer to my ſonne and h • yre, that he may vndoubtedly enter vppon't without the let or moleſtation of any man, at his or our pleaſure whenſoeuer.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tis ſo aſſurde vnto you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why then maiſter Baſie y'are a freeman ſir, you may deale in what you pleaſe, and goe whether you will. Why Tomazin, maiſter Eaſie is dome from Eſſex, bid him welcome in a cup of ſmall Beare.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not onely vilde, but in it tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: If it pleaſe you ſir, you knowe the houſe, you may viſite vs often▪ and dine with vs once a quarter.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.l: Confuſion light on you, your wealth and heyre,
Worme gnaw your conſcience, as the Moth your ware,
I am not the firſt heyre that rob'd, or beg'd.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent excellent, ſweet Spirits.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Landed maiſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Delicate ſhortyard, commodious Falſlight,
Hug and away, ſhift, ſhift.
Tis ſlight, not ſtrength that giues the greateſt lift.
Nowe my deſires are full—for this tyme,
Men may haue Cormorant wiſhes, but alas
A little thing three hundred pound a yeare,
Suffices nature, keepes life and ſoule together,
Ile haue 'em l • pt immediately.
sp.p:
I long to warme my ſelfe by'th wood,—A fine iourney in the Whitſun-holy dayes • yfaith, to ride downe with a number of Citizens, and their wiues, ſome vpon pillions, ſome vpon S • de ſaddles, I, and little Tomazin ith middle our ſome and heire S • m Quomodo in a peach colour Taffata Iack • t, ſome horſ •• length, or a long • ard before vs, there will be a fine ſhew on's I can tell you, where we Citizens will laugh, and lie downe ge • all our wiues with child againſt a bank and get vp againe, • ſtay, ha • aſt thou that wit yfaith twil▪ be admirable, to ſee how the very thought of greene fieldes puts a man into ſweet inuenttions. I will preſently poſſeſſe Sim
Quomodo of all the land, I haue a toy and ile doo't: and becau • e I ſee before mine eies that moſt of our heires proue notorious Rioters after our deaths, and that couſonage in the father wheeles about to follie in the ſonne, our poſteritie commonly foylde at the ſame weapon, at which we plaide rarely. And being the world • beaten worde, what's got ouer the Diuels backe, (that's by knauerie) muſt be ſpent vnder his bellie, (that's by lechery) being awake in theſe knowings, why ſhould not I oppoſe 'em now, and breake deſtinie of her cuſtome, preuenting that by pollicie, which without it muſt needes be Deſtinie? and I haue tooke the courſe, I will forthwith ſicken, call for my keyes, make my Will, and diſpoſe of all, giue my ſonne this bleſſing, that hee truſt no man, keepe his hand from a queane, and a Scriuener, liue in his fathers faith, and doe good to no bodie: then will I begin to raue like a fellow of a wide conſcience, and for all the worlde counterfeit to the life, that which I know I ſhall do when I die, take on for my golde, my landes, and my wrytings, grow worſe and worſe, call vpon the Diuell, and ſo make an ende▪ by this time I haue indented with a couple of ſearchers, who to vphold my deuice ſhall fray them out a'th Chamber with report of ſickneſſe, and ſo la, I ſtart vp, and recouer agen: for in this buſineſſe I will truſt, no not my ſpirits Falſlight & ſhortyard, but in diſguiſe note the condition of al, how pittiful my wife takes my death, which wil appear by Nouember in her eye, and the fall of the leaf inher bodie, but eſpecially by the coſt ſhe beſtows vpō my funeral, there ſhall I trie her loue and regard, my daughters marrying to my will & lyking, and my ſonnes affection after my diſpoſing: for to cōclude▪ I am as jealous of this land as of my wife, to know what would become of it after my deceaſe.

div.stage: Enter Curtezan with her diſguiſed father.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Tho I be poore, tis my glorie to liue honeſt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I prethee doe not leaue me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.l: To be bawde.
Hell has not ſuch an office,
I thought at firſt your minde had beene preſeru'd,
In vertue and in modeſtie of bloud,
that ſuch a face had not bene made to pleaſe the vnſetled Appetites of ſeuerall men,
Thoſe eyes turn'd vp through prayer, not through luſt,
But you are wicked, and my thoughts vniuſt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why thou art an vnreaſonable fellow yfaith, doe not al Trades liue by their ware, and yet cald honeſt Liuers? doe they not thriue beſt, when they vtter moſte, and make it away by the great? is not hole-ſale the chiefeſt marchandize? doe you thinke ſome Merchants could keepe their wiues ſo braue but for their hole-ſale? you'r fowly deceiu'd and you thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You are ſo glewde to puniſhent and ſhame, Your wordes ee'n deſerue whipping—to beare the habit of a Gentlewoman, and be in minde ſo diſtant.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why you foole you, are not Gentlewomen Sinners? and there's no coragious Sinner amongſt vs, but was a Gentlewoman by the Mothers ſide I warrant you: beſides, wee are not alwaies bound to thinke thoſe our fathers that marrie our Mothers, but thoſe that lye with our Mothers, and they may be Gentlemen borne & born agen for ought we know, you knowe.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: True: corruption may well be Generatious firſt, Wee're bad by nature, but by cuſtome worſt.

div.stage: A Bell Toales, a Confuſed crie within.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: My Father, O my Father.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: My ſweete Maiſter, dead!

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Runne boy, bid 'em ring out, hee's dead, hee's g • ne.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then is as arrant a knaue gone, as ere was cal'd vppon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: The happyeſt good that euer Shortyard felt,
I want to be expreſt, my mirth is ſuch,
To bee ſtruck now eene when his ioyes were hye,
Men onely kiſſe their knaueries, and ſo dye,
Iu'e often markt it.
Hee was a famous Coozner while he liu'd,
And now his Sonne ſhall reape it, ile ha the lands,
Let him Studye law after, tis no labour
to vndoe him for euer: but for Eaſie,
Onely good confidence did make him fooliſh,
And not the lack of Sence, that was not it,
Tis worldly craft beates downe a Schollars wit,
For this our Sonne and heyre now, hee
From his conception was entayl'd an Aſſe,
And hee ha's kept it well, twentie fiue yeares now,
Then the ſleighteſt art will doo't, the landes lye faire,
No Sinne to begger a deceiuers heyre.

div.stage: Enter Tomazin with Winefride her maide in haſt.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Heere Wenefride, heere, heere, heere, I haue alwaies found thee ſecret.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: You ſhall alwaies finde me ſo Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Take this letter and this Ring.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh how all the partes about me ſhake,—enquire for one Maiſter Eaſie at his olde lodging 'ith the Blackfryers,

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will indeed forſooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Tell him the partie that ſent him a hundred pound tother day to cōfort his heart, ha's likewiſe ſent him this Letter and this Ring, which has that vertue to recouer him agen for euer ſay—name no body Winifride.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Not ſo much as you forſooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Good Girle, thou ſhalt haue a mourning Gowne at the buryall of mine honeſtie.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And ile effect your will a my Fedelitie.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I doe account my ſelfe the happyeſt Widdowe that euer counterfetted weeping, in that I haue the leaſure now, both to doe that Gentleman good, and doe my ſelfe a pleaſure, but I muſt ſeeme like a hanging Moonea little wateriſh a while.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I entertaine both thee and thy Deuice,
Twill put e'm both to ſhame.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: That is my hope ſir,
Eſpecially that ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: Saue you ſweete widdowe,
I ſuffer for your heauineſſe.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O Maiſter Rerage, I haue loſt the deareſt huſband that euer woman did inioy.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: You muſt haue patience yet.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh talke not to mee of patience and you loue me, good Maiſter Rerage.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Yet if all tongues goe right, hee did not vſe you ſo wel as a man mought.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Nay, that's true indeed Maiſter Rerage, he nere vſd me ſo well as a woman might haue beene vſde, that's certain in troth ta's beene our greateſt falling out ſir, and though it be the part of a widdowe, to ſhow her ſelfe a woman for her Husbands death, yet when I remember al his vnkindneſſe, I cannot weepe a ſtroake yfaith Maiſter Rerage, and therefore wiſely did a great widdow in this land, comfort vp another, goe too Lady (quoth ſhe) leaue blubbering, thou thinkeſt vpon thy husbands good parts when thou ſheddeſt teares, doe but remember how often hee ha's laine from thee, and how many naughtie ſlipperie turnes he has done thee, & thou wilt nere weepe for him I warrant thee—you would not thinke how that counſell ha's wrought with me Maiſter Rerage, I could not diſpend another teare now, and you would giue me nere ſo much.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why I count you the wiſer Widdowe, it ſhowes you haue wiſdome, when you can checke your paſſion, for mine owne part, I haue no ſence to ſorrowe for his death, whoſe life was the onely Rub to my affection.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Troth and ſo it was to mine, but take courage now, your'e a Landed Gentleman, & my Daughter is ſeauen hundred pound ſtrong to ioyne with you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: But Lethe lyes'ith way.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: Let him lye ſtill, You ſhall treade ore him or ile faile in will.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Sweete widdowe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What a beloude man did I liue? my Seruants gall their fingers with ringing, my wiues cheeks ſmart with weeping,
ſtand in euerie corner, you may take water in my houſe— but am not I a wiſe foole now? what if my wife ſhould take my death ſo to heart, that ſhee ſhould ſicken vppon't, nay ſwone, nay dye? when did I heare of a woman doe ſo, let mee ſee,—Now I remember me, I thinke twas before my Time; yes, I haue heard of thoſe wiues that haue wept, and ſ • bd, and ſwound—marry I neuer heard but they recouered agen, that's a cōfort la, that's a comfort, & I hope ſo will mine —peace, tis nere vppon the time, I ſee, here comes the worſhipful liuerie, I haue the Hoſpital Boyes, I perceiue little Tomazin will beſtow coſt of me,—Ile liſten to the common cenſure now, how the world tongues me when my • are lyes lowe.

sp.speaker: 1. Liue.
sp.p: Who Quomodo? meerely enricht by ſhifts, And couſnages, beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I ſee the world is verye loath to praiſe me,
Tis Rawlye friendes with me, I cannot blame it,
For what I haue done, has beene to vexe and ſhame it.
Heere comes my Sonne, the hope, the landed heyre,
Ont whoſe rare thrift, will ſay mens tongues you lye,
Ile keepe by lawe what was got craftily.
Me thinkes I heare him ſay ſo:
He does ſalute the liuerie with good grace,
And ſolemne Geſture—

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: oh my yong Worſhipful M. you haue parted from a deere Father, a wiſe and proui-dent father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Art thou growne an Aſſe now?

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: Such an honeſt Father—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Prethee Beadle leaue thy lying, I am ſcarce able to endure thee yfaith, what honeſty didſt thou ere know by my Father ſpeake, rule your tongue Beadle leaſt I make you proue it, and then I knowe what will become of you, tis the ſcuruy eſt thing i'th earth to belye the dead ſo, and hee's a beaſtly Sonne and heyre that wil ſtand by, and heare his father belyed to his face, hee will nere proſper I warrant him, Troth if I be not aſham'd to goe to Church with him, I would I might be hang'd, I feare ſuch filthye Tales goe on him, oh
if I had knowne hee had beene ſuch a lewde fellow in his life hee ſhould nere haue kept me company.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh—o—o!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But I am glad hee's gone, tho twere long firſt, Shortyard and I will reuell it yfaith, I haue made him my Rentgatherer alreadie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee ſhall bee ſpeedilye diſinherited, hee gettes not a foote, not the Crowne of a Mole-hill, ile ſooner make a courtyer my heyre for teaching my wife trickes then thee, my moſte neglectfull Sonne? Oh now the coarſe, I ſhall obſerue yet farder.

div.stage: A counterfet Coarſe brought in, Tomazin, and al the mourners equally counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O my moſte modeſt, vertuous and remembring wife, ſhe ſhall haue all when I dye, ſhe ſhall haue all.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Maiſter Eaſie? tis, oh what ſhift ſhall I make now? oh—

div.stage: Falls downe in a fayned ſwound.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweete wife ſhe ſownes, ile let her alone, ile haue no mercie at this time, ile not ſee her, ile follow the coarſe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ:
sp.p: The Deuill grinde thy Bones, thou co • ſning Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Giue her a little more ayre, tilt vp her head, comfort thy ſelfe good widdowe, doe not fall like a Beaſt for a huſband, there's more then wee can well tell where to put e'm, good ſoule.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall be well anon.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Fye, you haue no patience yfaith, I haue buried foure Husbands, and neuer offered e'm ſuch abuſe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Couzen, how doe you?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Sorry to ſee you ill Couze.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: The worſt is paſt I hope.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I hope ſo to.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Lend me your hand ſweet Couze I haue troubled you

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: No trouble indeed forſooth—Good Couzen haue a care of her, comfort her vp as much as you can, and all little ynough I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: My moſte ſweete loue.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: My life is not ſo deere.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I haue alwaies pittyed you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Y'aue ſhowne it heere. And giuen the deſperate hope?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Delay not now, y'aue vnderſtood my loue, I haue a prieſt readye, this is the fitteſt ſeaſon, no eye offends vs, Let this kiſſe Reſtore thee to more wealth, me to more bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: The Angels haue prouided for me.

div.head: Incipit Quintus et Vltimus.
div.stage: Enter Shortyard with writings, hauing couſned Sim Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I haue not Scope ynough within my breſt,
To keepe my ioyes containde: I'me Quomodoes
heire: the Lands aſſurances, and all are mine
(I haue tript his Sonnes heeles vp) aboue the ground,
His father left him: had I not encouragement?
Do not I knowe what proues the Fathers pray?
The Sonne nere lookes on't, but it melts away.
Doe not I knowe the wealth that's got by fraude?
Slaue's ſhare it like the ritches of a Bawde.
Why tis a curſe vnquenchable, nere cooles.
Knaues ſtill commit their conſciences to fooles:
And they betray who o'wde em, heeres all the bonds,
All Eaſies writings, let me ſee:

div.stage: Enter Quomodoes Wife marryed to Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now my deſires weare crownes.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: My ioyes exceede, Man is neere healthfull, till his follyes bleede.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh, beholde the Villaine, who in all thoſe ſhapes Confounded your eſtate.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: That ſlaue, that villaine.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: So many Acres of good meadowe—

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I heare you ſir.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Rogue, Shortyard, Blaſtfield, Serjeant, Deputy, couſner

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Holde, holde.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I thirſt the execution of his eares.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hate you that office,

sp.speaker: Eaſi.
sp.p: Ile ſtrip him bare for puniſhment and ſhame.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why doe but heare me ſir, you will not thinke what I haue done for you.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Giuen his Sonne my Lands.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Why looke you, tis not ſo, your not tolde true,
I haue Cooſned him agen meerely for you,
Meerely for you ſir, twas my meaning then
That you ſhould wed her, and haue all agen.
sp.p: A my troth 'its true ſir: looke you then heere ſir, you ſhall not miſſe a little ſcrowle ſir, pray ſir, let not the Cittie knowe me for a knaue, there be ritcher men would enuie my preferment if I ſhould be knowne before e'm.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.l: Villaine, my hate to more reuenge is drawne,
When ſlaues are found, tis their baſe Arte to fawne,
Within there—.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? freſh warders.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: This is the other, binde him faſt, haue I found you Maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: This is the fruite of Craft,
Like him that ſhootes vp hye, lookes for the ſhaft
And findes it in his fore-head, ſo does hit
The Arrowe of our fate, wit deſtroyes wit:
The head the bodyes bane, and his owne beares,
You hae Corne enough, you neede not reape mine eares,
Sweete Maiſter Blaſtfield.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I loath his voice, away.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: What happyneſſe was heere, but are you ſure you haue all?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I hope ſo my ſweete wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What difference there is in Husbands, not onelye in one thing, but in all.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Heeres good deedes and bad deedes, the writings that keep my lands to me, and the bonds that gaue it away from me.
sp.l: Theſe my good deedes ſhall to more ſafetie turne,
And theſe my bad haue their deſarts and burne.
Ile ſee thee agen preſently, reade there.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Did he want all, who would not loue his care?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What a wife haſt thou Epheſtian—Quomodo, ſo louing ſo mindefull of her duetye not onely ſeene to weep but knowne to ſwone, I knew a Widdow about Saint Antlings ſo forgetfull of hir firſt Husband, that ſhe marryed agen within the tweluemonth, nay ſome berladye within the month: there were ſights to be ſeen, had they my wiues true ſorrows ſeauen nor ſeauen yeares would drawe e'm to the ſtake, I would moſte tradeſmen had ſuch a wife as I, they hope they haue, wee muſt all hope the beſt: thus in her honour.

div.l: A modeſt wife is ſuch a Iewell,
He that's honeſt, and not cruell,
Is the likelyeſt man to owe it.
div.p: And that's I, I made it by my ſelfe, and comming to her as a Beadle for my reward this morning, ile ſee how ſhee takes my death next her heart.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now Beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Bleſſe your miſtrisſhips eyes from too many teares, Although you haue loſt a wiſe and worſhipfull Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You come for your due Beadle, heere 'ith houſe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Moſt certaine, the Hoſpitall money and mine owne poore forty pence.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I muſt craue a diſcharge from you Beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Call your man, ile heartilye ſee my hand to a Memorandum.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You deale the truel yer.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Good wench ſtill.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: George, heere is the Beadle come for his money, draw a Memorandum that he has receiued all his due he can claim heere ith houſe after this funerall.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What politick directions ſhee giues him, all to ſecure her ſelfe, tis time yfaith now to pitty her, ile diſcouer my ſelfe to her ere I goe, but came it off with ſome liuely ieſt now, that were admyrable: I haue it? after the memorandum is written and all, ile ſet my owne name too't Epheſtian Quomodo,
ſheele ſtart, ſheele wonder how Epheſt▪ Quomodo came the ther that was buried yeſterday: y'are beſet little Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ninteene, twentie fiue pound, 1, 2, 3, & 4. d.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: So, we ſhall haue good ſport, when tis read:

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: How now Ladie, paying away money ſo faſt?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The Beadles due here ſir

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Whoſe? tis Eaſie, what makes Eaſie in my houſe, Hee is not my wiues ouer ſeer I hope:

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Whats here?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He makes me ſweate.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Memorandum that I haue receiued of Richard Eaſie, all my due I can claime here i'th houſe▪ or any hereafter for me: In witneſſe whereof, I haue ſet to mine owne hand, Epheſtian Qommodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What haue I done? was I mad?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Epheſtian Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, well, what then ſir? get you out of my houſe, Firſt you maiſter Prodigall had land, away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What is the Beadle drunke or mad? Where are my men to thruſt him out a doores.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not ſo good Tomazin not ſo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: This fellow muſt be whipt.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Thanke you good wife.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I can no longer beare him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay ſweete husband.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Husband I me vndone, beggard, couzend, confounded for euer: married alreadie? will it pleaſe you knowe mee now miſtris Harlot, and maſter Horner, who am I now?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, hee's as like my tother husband as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ile haue iudgement, ile bring you before a Iudge, you ſhall feele wife whether my fleſh be dead or no, ile tickle you yfaith, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The Iudge that heele ſolicite knowes me well.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Lets on then, and our greeuances firſt tell.

div.stage: Enter Lethe with officers, taken with his Harlot.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Here they come.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: O where.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Hart of ſhame, vpō my wedding morning ſo diſgracd▪
Haue you ſo little conſcience Officers,
You will not take a bribe?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Maſter Lethe we may lie together lawfully hereafter, for we are coupled together before people ynow yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: There goes the ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.l: Pardon my wilfull blindneſſe and enioy me.
For now the difference appeares too plaine,
Betwixt a baſe ſlaue and a true Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I doe embrace thee in the beſt of loue,
How ſoone affections fail, how ſoone they proue.

div.stage: Enter Iudge, Eaſie, and Tomazin in talke with him.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: His couſnages are odious, he the plaintife,
Not onely framde deceitfull in his life,
But ſo to mocke his funerall.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.l: Moſt iuſt.
The Liuerie all aſſembled, mourning weedes,
Throughout his houſe een down to his laſt ſeruāt
The Herauld richly hirde to lend him Armes,
Faind from his Aunceſtors, which I dare ſweare knewe no
other Armes but thoſe they labour'd with,
All preparations furniſht, nothing wanted
Saue that which was the cauſe of all, his death,
If he be liuing.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.p: Twas an impious part.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.l: We are not certaine yet it is himſelfe,
But ſome falſe ſpirit that aſſumes his ſhape,
And ſeekes ſtill to deceiue mee.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh are you come? my Lord? their here, good morrow Tomazin.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.p: Now what are you?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I am Quomodo my Lord, & this my wife,
Thoſe my two men, that are bound wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: How are we ſure y'are he?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh you cannot miſſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: Ile trie you. Are you the man that liu'd the famous couſner?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O no my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Did you deceiue this Gentleman of his right,
And laid Nets ore his land?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Then y'are not Quomodo but a counterfet,
Lay hands on him, and beare him to the whip.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay a little I pray, now I remember me my Lord, I couſned him indeed, tis wondrous true.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Then I dare ſweare this is no counterfet.
Let all doubts ceaſe this man is Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why la you now, you would not beleeue this, I am found what I am.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: But ſetting theſe thy odious ſhifts apart,
Why did that thought prophane, enter thy breſt,
To mocke the world with thy ſuppoſed death?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Conceiue you not that my Lord? a policy.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: For hauing gotten the lands I thirſted ſtill,
To know what fate would follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Iu •
sp.p: Being ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your Lorpſhip apprehends me.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: I thinke I ſhall anon.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: And thereupon,
I out of policie poſſeſt my ſonne,
Which ſince I haue found lewd, and now intend
To diſinherit him for euer,
Not onely this was in my death ſet downe,
But thereby a firme triall of my wife,
Her conſtant ſorrowes, her remembring vertues,
All which are Dewes, the ſhine of a next morning 'dries 'em vp all I ſee't.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Did you profeſſe wiſe couſenage, and would dare
To put a woman to her two dayes choice,
When of a minute do's it?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Leſſe, a moment
The twinckling of an eye, a glimpſe, ſcarce ſomthing do's it,
Your Lordſhip yet will graunt ſhe is my wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O heauen!

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: After ſome penance, and the Deues of law
I muſt acknowledge that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I ſcarce like
Thoſe Deues of lawe.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.l: My Lord, altho the law too gently lot his wife,
The wealth he left behind he cannot chalenge.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Behold his hand againſt it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He do's deuize all meanes to make mee mad, that I may no more lie with my wife in perfect memorie, I know't b • t • et the landes will maintaine me in my wits: the lande will doe ſo much for mee.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: In witneſſe whereof I haue ſet to mine owne hand,
Eph • ſtian Quomodo.
Tis firme enough your owne ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: A ieſt my Lord, I did I knew not what.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: It ſhould ſeeme ſo, deceit is her owne foe
Craftily gets, and childiſhly lets goe.
But yet the lands are his.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: No my good Lord, the lands know the right heire, I am their maſter once more.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Haue you the lands?

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: Yes truly I praiſe heauen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Is this good dealing? are there ſuch conſciences abroad, how? which way could he come by 'em?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My Lord ile quickly reſolue you that it comes to me
This couſner whom too long I call'd my patrone,
To my thought dying, and the foole his ſonne
Poſſeſt of all, which my braine partly ſweat for,
I held it my beſt vertue, by a plot
To get from him what for him was ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O beaſtly Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: When no ſooner mine,
But I was glad more quickly to reſigne.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: Craft once diſcouer'd ſhewes her abiect line.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: He hits me euery where, for craft once knowne,
Do's teach fooles wit, leaues the deceiuer none.
My deedes haue cleft me, cleft me.

div.stage: Enter Officers with Lethe and the Harlot.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Roome there.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: A little yet to raiſe my ſpirit.
Here maiſter Lethe comes to wed my Daughter.
That's all the ioy is left me: ha? who's this?

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: What crimes haue thoſe brought foorth?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The ſhame of luſt,
Moſt viciouſly on this his wedding morning,
This man was ceazde in ſhame with that bolde Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Why, tis ſhe he meanes to matrye.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No in truth.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: In truth you doe.
Who for his wife his Harlot doth preferre,
Good reaſon tis, that he ſhould martie her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I craue it on my knees, ſuch was his vowe at firſt,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Ile ſay ſo too
And worke out mine owne ſafetie,
Such was his vowe at firſt, indeede my Lord,
How ere his moode has chang'd him?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O vilde ſlaue!

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He ſayes it true my Lord,

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Reſt content,
He ſhall both marrie and taſte puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Oh intollerable! I beſeech your good Lordſhip if I muſt haue an outward puniſhment, let me not marrie an inward, whoſe laſtes will nere out, but growe worſe and worſe: I haue a wife ſtaies for me this morning with ſeauen hundred pound in her purſſe, let me be ſpeedily whipt and be gone, I beſeech your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Hee ſpeakes no truth my Lord, behold the Virgin,
Wife to a well eſteemed Gentleman,
Loathing the Sin he followes.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I was betrayed, yes faith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: His owne Mother my Lord,
Which hee confeſt through ignorance, and diſdaine,
His name ſo chang'd to abuſe the world and her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
Marry a Hailot, why not? tis an honeſt mans fortune,
I pray did not one of my Coūtriemen marrye my Siſter? why well then, if none ſhould be marryed but thoſe that are honeſt where ſhould a man ſeeke a wife after Chriſtmas? I pitty that Gentleman, that has nine Daughters to beſtowe, and ſeauen of e'm Seeded already, they wil be good ſtuffe by that time, I doe beſeech your Lordſhip to remoue the puniſhment, I am content to marrie her.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: There's no remouing of your puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Vnleſſe one heere aſſembled
Whom you haue moſt vnnaturally a buſde, beget your pardon.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Who ſhould that be?
Or who would doote, that has beene ſo abuſde?
A troubleſome pennance—ſir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Knaue in your face, leaue your mocking, Andrew, marrie your Qeane and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maiſter Eaſie.

sp.speaker: Eaſ.
sp.p: I'me ſorrie you take ſuch a bad courſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maiſter Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Enquire my right name agen next time, now goe your waies like an Aſſe as you came.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maſſe I forget my mother all this while, Ile make her doo't at firſt, pray mother your bleſſing for once.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Calſt me Mother? out, I defie thee ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Call me ſlaue as much as you will, but doe not ſhame me now, let the world knowe you are my Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Let me not haue this Villaine put vpon me I beſeech your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: Hee's iuſtly curſt, ſhe loathes to know him now,
Whome he before did as much loath to knowe,
Wilt thou beleeue me woman?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: That's ſoone done.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Then knowe him for a Villaine, tis thy Sonne,

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Art thou Andrew my wicked Sonne Andrew?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You would not beleeue me Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
How art thou chang'd? Is this ſute fit for thee? a Tooth-drawers Sonne,
this countrie has ee'ne ſpoilde thee ſince thou camſt heather, thy manners better then thy cloathes, but now whole cloathes and ragged manners, it may well be ſaide that truth goes naked, for when thou hadſt ſcarce a ſhirt thou hadſt more truth about thee.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: Thou art thine owne affliction Quomodo:
Shortyard we baniſh, tis our pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hence foorth no woman ſhall complaine for meaſure.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: And that all Error from our workes may ſtand,
We banniſh Falſlight euermore the land.
